div.head: To the most Illustrious Prince WILLIAM, DUKE, MARQUIS, and EARL OF NEWCASTLE, &c.
div.p:
THe Favours have been so many and so great, which your Grace's unwearied Bounty has conferred upon me, that I cannot omit this oportunity of telling the World, how much I have been obliged, and by whom. My Gratitude will not suffer me to smother the favoÃÑurs in silence; nor the Pride they have rais'd me to, let me conceal, the Name of so Excellent a Patron. The honour of being favoured by the great Newcastle, is equal with any real Merit, I am sure infinitely above mine. Yet the encouragement I receive from your Grace, is the certain way to make
the World believe I have some desert, or to create in me the most favourable thoughts of my self. My Name may thus, when otherwise it would perish, live in after Ages, under the protection of your Grace's, which, is famous abroad, and will be Eterniz'd in this Nation, for your Wit beyond all Poets; Judgment and Prudence, before all Statesmen; Courage and Conduct, above all Generals; Constancy and Loyalty, beyond all Subjects; Virtue and Temperance, above all Philosophers; for skill in Weapons, and Horsemanship, and all other Arts befitting your Quality, excelling all Noblemen: And lastly, for those eminent Services in defence of your King and Countrey, with an Interest and Power much exceeding all, and with Loyalty equalling any Nobleman. And indeed, the first was so great, that it might justly have made the greatest Prince afraid of it, had it not been so strongly secured by the latter.

All these Heroick Qualities I admired, and worshipped at a distance, before I had the Honour to wait upon your Grace at your House. For so vast was your Bounty to me, as to find me out in my obscurity, and oblige me several years, before you saw me at Welbeck; where (when I arrived) I found a Respect so extremely above the meanness of my Condition, that I still received it with blushes; having had nothing to recommend me, (but the Birth and Education, without the Fortune of a Gentleman) besides some Writings of mine, which your Grace was pleased to like. Then was soon added to my former Worship and Admiration,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ „Äà‚óä„Äâ, and infinite Gratitude, and a Pride of being „Äà‚óä„Äâ by one, in whom I observ'd a Majesty equal with greatest Princes, yet Affability exceeding ordinary Gentlemen. A Greatness, that none e'r approached without Awe, or parted from without Satisfaction.

Then (by the great honour I had to be daily admitted into your, Grace's publick and private Conversation) I observed that admirable Experience and Judgment surmounting all the Old, and that vigorousness of Wit, and Smartness of Expression, exceeding all the Young, I ever knew; and not onely in sharp and apt Replies, the most excellent way of pursuing a Discourse; but (which is much more difficult) by giving easie and unforced occasions, the most admirable way of begining one; and all this adapted to men of all Circumstances and Conditions. Your Grace being able to discourse with every man in his own way, which, as it shows you to be a most accurate Observer of all mens tempers, so it shows your Excellency in all their Arts. But when I had the favour daily to be admitted to your Grace's more retired Conversation, when I alone enjoyed the honour, I must declare, I never spent my hours with that pleasure, or improvement; nor shall I ever enough acknowledge that, and the rest of the Honours done me by your Grace, as much above my Condition as my Merit.

And now, my Lord, after all this, imagine not I intend this small Present of a Play (though favoured here by those I most wish it should be) as any return; for all the Services of my life cannot make a sufficient one. I onely lay hold on this occasion, to publish to the World your great Favours, and the grateful Acknowledgments of,

closer.signed: Your Grace's Most obliged, humble, and obedient Servant, THO. SHADWELL.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: THe story from which I took the hint of this Play, is famous all over Spain, Italy, and France: It was first put into a Spanish Play (as I have been told) the Spaniards having a Tradition (which they believe) of such a vicious Spaniard, as is represented in this Play. From them the Italian Comedians took it, and from them the French took it, and four several French Plays were made upon the Story.

The Character of the Libertine, and consequently those of his Friends, are borrow'd; but all the Plot, till the latter end of the Fourth Act, is new: And all the rest is very much varied from any thing which has been done upon the Subject.

I hope the Readers will excuse the Irregularities of the Play, when they consider, that the Extravagance of the Subject forced me to it: And I had rather try new ways to please, than to write on in the same Road, as too many do. I hope that the severest Reader will not be offended at the representation of those Vices, on
which they will see a dreadful punishment inflicted. And I have been told by a worthy Gentleman, that many years agon (when first a Play, was made upon this Story in Italy) he has seen it acted there by the name of Atheisto Fulminato, in Churches, on Sundays, as a part of Devotion; and some, not of the least Judgment and Piety here, have thought it rather an useful Moral, than an incouragement to vice.

I have no reason to complain of the success of this Play, since it pleased those, whom, of all the world, I would please most. Nor was the Town unkind to it, for which reason I must applaud my good Fortune, to have pleased with so little pains: there being no Act in it, which cost me above five days writing; and the last two, (the Play-house having great occasion for a Play) were both written in four days, as several can testifie. And this I dare declare, notwithstanding the soul, course, and ill-manner'd censure passed upon them, (who write Plays in three, four, or sive weeks time) by a rough hobling Rhimer, in his Postscript to another Man's Play, which he spoil'd, and call'd, Love and Revenge; I having before publickly owned the writing two Plays in so short a time. He ought not to have measured any Man's Abilities, who writes for the Stage with his own; for some may write that in three weeks, which he cannot in three years. But he is angry, that any man should write sense so easily, when he finds it so laborious a thing to write, even Fustian, that he is believed to have been three years drudging upon the
Conquest of China‚ñ™ But he ought not to be called a Poet, who cannot write ten times a better in three weeks.

I cannot here pass by his sawcy Epistle to this Conquest, which (instead of expressions of just respect, due to the Birth and Merit of his Patron) is stuffed with railing against others. And first, he begins with the vanity of his Tribe. What Tribe that really is, it is not hard to ghess; but all the Poets will bear me witness it is not theirs, who are sufficiently satisfied, that he is no more a Poet than Servant to his Majesty, as he presumes to write himself; which I wonder he will do, since Protections are taken off: I know not what Place he is Sworn into in Extraordinary, but I am sure there is no such thing as Poet in Extraordinary.

But I wonder (after all his railing) he will call these Poets his Brethren; if they were, me-thinks he might have more natural affection than to abuse his Brethren: but he might have spared that Title, for we can find no manner of Relation betwixt him and them; for they are all Gentlemen, that will not own him, or keep him company: and that, perhaps, is the cause which makes him so angry with them, to tax them, in his ill-manner'd Epistle, with Impudence, which he (having a particular affection for his own vice) calls by the name of Frailty. Impudence indeed is a very pretty Frailty.

But (what ever the Poets are guilty of) I wish he had as much of Poetry in him, as he has of that Frailty, for the good of the Duke's Theatre; they might then
have hopes of gaining as much by his good Sense, as as they have lost by his Fustian.

Thus much I thought sit to say in vindication of the Poets, though, I think, he has not Authority enough (with men of sense) to fix any calumny upon the Tribe, as he calls it. For which reason I shall never trouble my self to take notice of him hereafter, since all men of Wit will think, that he can do the Poets no greater injury, than pretending to be one. Nor had I said so much in answer to his course railing, but to reprehend his Arrogance, and lead him to a little better knowledge of himself; nor does his base Language in his Postscript deserve a better Return.

lg.l: OUr Author sent me hither for a Scout,
To spy what bloudy Criticks were come out;
Those Piccaroons in Wit, wh'infest this Road,
And snap both Friend and Foe that come abroad.
This savage Party crueller appears,
Than in the Channel Ostend Privateers.
You in this Road, or sink or plunder all,
Remorsless as a Storm on us you fall:
But as a Merchant, when by storms distress'd,
Flings out his bulkey Goods to save the rest,
Hoping a Calm may come, he keeps the best.
In this black Tempest which o'r us impends,
Near Rocks and Quick sands, and no Ports of Friends,
Our Poet gives this over to your rage,
The most irregular Play upon the Stage,
As wild and as extravagant as th' Age.
Now, angry men, to all your splenes give vent;
When all your fury has on this been spent,
Else-where you with much worse shall be content.
The Poet has no hopes you'll be appeas'd,
Who come on purpose but to be displeas'd.
Such corrupt Judges should excepted be,
Who can condemn before they hear or see.
Ne'r were such bloudy Criticks yet in fashion;
You damn by absolute Predestination.
But why so many to run one man down?
It were a mighty triumph when y'have done.
Our scarcity of Plays you should not „Äà‚óä„Äâ,
When by foul „Äà‚óä„Äâ „Äà‚óä„Äâ destroy the Game.
Let him but have fair play, and he may then
Write himself into favour once again.
If after this your anger you'll reveal,
To Caesar he must make his just appeal;
There Mercy and Judgment equally do meet,
To pardon Faults, and to encourage Wit..

list.head: The Persons represented.
list.item: Don John. THe Libertine; a rash fearless Man, guilty of all Vice.
Leonora. Don John's Mistris, abused by him, yet follows him for Love.
Maria, Her Maid, abused by Don John, and following him for Revenge.
Don Francisco. Father to Clara and Flavia.
Six Women. All Wives to Don John.
Two Gentlemen. Intended for Husbands to Clara and Flavia.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: Enter Don John, Don Lopez, Don Antonio, Jacomo, Don John's Valet.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: T

lg.l: Hus far without a bound we have enjoy'd
Our prosp'rous pleasures, which dull Fools call
[Sins;
Laugh'd at old feeble Judges, and weak Laws;
And at the fond fantastick thing, call'd Conscience,
Which serves for nothing but to make men Cowards;
An idle fear of future misery;
And is yet worse than all that we can fear.
Conscience made up of dark and horrid thoughts,
Rais'd from the fumes of a distemper'd Spleen.
A sensless fear, would make us contradict
The onely certain Guide, Infallible Nature;
And at the call of Melancholly Fools,
(Who stile all actions which they like not, Sins)
To silence all our Natural appetites.
Yet those conscientious Fools, that would perswade us
To I know not what, which they call Piety,
Have in reserve private delicious sins,
Great as the happy Libertine enjoys,
With which, in corners, wantonly they roul.
Don John, thou art our Oracle; thou hast
Dispell'd the fumes which once clowded our brains.
By thee, we have got loose from Education,
And the dull slavery of Pupillage,
Recover'd all the liberty of Nature,
Our own strong Reason now can go alone,
Without the feeble props of splenatick Fools,
Who contradict our common Mother, Nature.
Nature gave us our Senses, which we please:
Nor does our Reason War against our Sense.
„Äà‚óä„Äâ Natures order Sense should guide our Reason,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ to the mind all objects Sense conveys.
„Äà‚óä„Äâ ‚óè‚Ä¶ools for shaddows lose substantial pleasures,
for idle tales abandon true delight,
And solid joys of day, for empty dreams at night.
Away, thou foolish thing, thou chollick of the mind,
Thou Worm by ill-digesting stomachs bred:
In spight of thee, well surfeit in delights,
And never think ought can be ill that's pleasant.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: A most excellent Sermon, and no doubt, Gentlemen, you have edisi'd much by it.

lg.l: Away! thou formal phlegmatick Coxcomb, thou
Hast neither courage nor yet wit enough
To sin thus. Thou art my dull conscientious Pimp.
And when I am wanton with my Whore within,
Thou, with thy Beads and Pray'r-book, keep'st the door.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Sir, I find your Worship is no more afraid to be damn'd, than other fashionable Gentlemen of the Age: but, me-thinks, Halters and Axes should terrisie you. With reverence to your Worships, I've seen civiller men hang'd, and men of as pretty parts too. There's scarce a City in Spain but is too hot for you, you have committed such outrages wheresoe'r you come.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Come, for diversion, pray let's hear your Fool preach a little.

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.p: For my part, I cannot but be troubled, that I shall lose my honour by you, Sir; for people will be apt to say, Like Master, like Man.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Your honour, Rascal, a Sow-gelder may better pretend to it.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: But I have another scruple, Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: I fear I shall be hang'd in your company.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: That's an honour you will ne'r have courage to deserve.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: It is an honour I am not ambitious of.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Why does the Fool talk of hanging? we scorn all Laws.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: It seems so‚ñ™ or you would not have cut your Elder Brother's throat. Don Lopez.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Why, you Coxcomb, he kept a good Estate from me‚ñ™ and I could not Whore and Revel fufficiently without it.

sp.speaker: D. Anto.
sp.p: Look you, Jacomo, had he not reason?

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Yes, Antonio, so had you to get both your Sisters with Child; 'twas very civil, I take it.

sp.speaker: D. Anto.
sp.p: Yes, you Fool, they were lusty young handsome Wenches, and pleas'd my appetite. Besides, I sav'd the Honour of the Family by it‚ñ™ for if I had not, some body else would.

lg.l: O horrid villany!
But you are both Saints to my hopeful Master‚ñ™
I'll turu him loose to Belzebub himself,
He shall out-do him at his own Weapons.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I, you Rascal.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Oh no, Sir, you are as innocent. To cause your good old Father to be kill'd was nothing.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: It was something, and a good thing too, Sirra: his whole design was to debar me of my pleasures: he kept his purse from me, and could not be content with that, but still would preach his sensless Morals to me, his old dull foolish stuff against my pleasure. I caus'd him to be sent I know not whether. But he believ'd he was to go to Heav'n; I care not where he is, since I am rid of him.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Cutting his throat was a very good return for his begetting of you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: That was before he was aware on't, 'twas for his own sake, he ne'r thought of me in the business.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Heav'n bless us!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: You Dog, I shall beat out your brains, if you dare be so impudent as to pray in my company.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: good Sir, I have done, I have done‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Prethee let the insipid Fool go on.

lg.l: Let's hear the Coxcomb number up your crimes,
The patterns we intend to imitate.
Sir, let me lay your horrid crimes before you:
The unhappy minute may perhaps arrive,
When the sense of 'em may make you penitent.

sp.speaker: D. Anto.
sp.p: 'Twere better thou wer't hang'd.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Repent! Cowards and Fools do that.

lg.l: Your valiant well-bred Gentlemen never repent:
But what should I repent of?

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: After the murder of your Father, the brave Don Pedro, Governour of Sevil, for whom the Town are still in grief, was, in his own house, barb'rously kill'd by you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Barbarously, you lie, you Rascal, 'twas finely done; I run him through the Lungs as handsomely, and kill'd him as decently, and as like a Gentleman as could be. The jealous Coxcomb deserv'd death, he kept his Sister from me; her eyes would have kill'd me if I had not enjoy'd her, which I could not do without killing him: Besides, I was alone, and kill'd him hand to fist.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: I never knew you go to Church but to take Sanctuary for a Murder, or to rob Churches of their Plate.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Heav'n needs not be serv'd in Plate, but I had use on't.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: How often have you scal'd the Walls of Monasteries? Two Nuns, I know, you ravish'd, and a third you dangerously wounded for her violent resistance.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: The perverse Jades were uncivill, and deserv'd such usage.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Some thirty Murders, Rapes innumerable, frequent Sacrilege, Parricide; in short, not one in all the Catalogue of Sins have scap'd you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: My bus'ness is my pleasure, that end I will always compass, without scrupling the means; there is no right or wrong, but what conduces to, or hinders pleasure. But, you tedious insipid Rascal, if I hear more of your Morality, I will Carbonado you.

sp.speaker: D. Anto.
sp.p: We live the life of Sense, which no fantastick thing, call'd Reason, shall controul.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: My reason tells me, I must please my Sense.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: My appetites are all I'm sure I have from Heav'n, since they are Natural, and them I always will obey.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: I doubt it not, Sir, therefore I desire to shake hands and part.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: D'ye hear, Dog, talk once more of parting, and I will saw your Wind-pipe. I could find in my heart to cut your Rascal's Nose off, and save the Pox a labour: I'll do't, Sirra, have at you.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Good Sir, be not so transported; I will live, Sir‚ñ™ and will serve you in any thing; I'll fetch a Wench, or any thing in the world Sir. O how I tremble at this Tyrant's rage.

sp.speaker: D. Anto.
sp.p: Come, 'tis night, we lose time to our adventures.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: I have bespoke Musick for our Serenading.

lg.l: Let's on, and live the noble life of Sense.
To all the powers of Love and mighty Lust,
In spight of formal Fops I will be just.
What ways soe'r conduce to my delight,
My Sense instructs me, I must think 'em right.
On, on, my Soul, and make no stop in pleasure,
They're dull insipid Fools that live by measure.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: What will become of me? if I should leave him, he's so revengeful, he would travel o'r all Spain to find me out, and cut my throat. I cannot live long with him neither: I shall be hang'd, or knock'd o'th' head, or share some dreadful Fate or other with him. 'Tis just between him and me, as between the Devil and the Witch, Who repents her bargain, and would be free from future ills, but for the fear of present durst not venture.
Here comes Leonora, one of those multitudes of Ladies, he has sworn, li'd to, and betray'd.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Jacomo, where is Don John? I could not live to endure
a longer absence from him. I have sigh'd and wept my self away I „Äà‚óä„Äâ but have no life left in me. His coldness and his absence „Äà‚óä„Äâ given me fearful and killing „Äà‚óä„Äâ. Where is my Dear?

sp.speaker: „Äà‚óä„Äâ.
sp.p: Your Dear, Madam! he's your's no more.

sp.speaker: „Äà‚óä„Äâ.
sp.p: Heav'n! what do I hear? Speak, is he dead?

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: To you he is.

lg.l: Ah me, has he forgot his Vows and Oaths?
Has he no Conscience, Faith, or Honour left?

sp.speaker: „Äà‚óä„Äâ.
sp.p: Left, Madam, he ne'r had any.

sp.speaker: „Äà‚óä„Äâ.
sp.p: It is impossible, you speak this out of malice sure.

sp.speaker: „Äà‚óä„Äâ.
sp.p: There's no man knows him better than I do. I have a greater respect for you, than for any he has betray'd, and will undeceive you: he is the most perfidious Wretch alive.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Has he forgot the Sacred Contract, which was made privately betwixt us, and confirm'd before the altar, during the time of holy Mass?

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: All times and places are alike to him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh how assiduous was he in his passion! how many thousand vows and sighs he breath'd! what tears he wept, seeming to suffer all the cruel pangs which Lovers e'r endur'd! how eloquent were all his words and actions!

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: His person and his parts are excellent, but his base vices are beyond all measure: why would you believe him?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: My own love brib'd me to believe him: I saw the man I lov'd more than the world. Oft on his knees, with his eyes up to Heav'n, kissing my hand with such an amorous heat, and with such ardor, breathing fervent vows of loyal Love, and venting sad complaints of extreme sufferings. I poor easie Soul, flattering my „Äà‚óä„Äâ to think he meant as I did, lost all my Sexes faculty, Distembling; and in a moneth must I be thus betray'd?

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Poor Lady! I cannot but have bowels for you; your sad Narration makes me weep in sadness: but you are better „Äà‚óä„Äâ than others. I ne'r knew him constant a fortnight before.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Then, then he promis'd he would marry me.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p:
If he were to live here one moneth longer, he wou'd marry half the Town, ugly and handsome, old and young:
nothing that's Female comes amiss to him‚Äî

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Does he not fear a thunder bolt from Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: No, nor a Devil from Hell. He owns no Deity but his voluptuous appetite, whose satisfaction he will compass by Murders, Rapes, Treasons, or ought else. But pray let me ask you one civil question, Did you not give him earnest of your Body, Madam.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Mock not my misery.
Oh! that confounds me. Ah! I thought him true, and lov'd him so, I could deny him nothing.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Why, there 'tis; I fear you have, or else he wou'd have marri'd you: he has marri'd six within this moneth, and promis'd fifteen more, all whom he has enjoy'd, and left, and is this night gone on some new adventure, some Rape or Murder, some such petty thing.

lg.l: Oh Monster of impiety!
Oh false Don John! wonder of cruelty!

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: What a pox does she swound at the news! Alas! poor Soul, she has mov'd me now to pity, as she did to love. Ha! the place is private‚Äî If I should make use of a Natural Receit to refresh her, and bring her to life again, 'twould be a great pleasure to me, and no trouble to her. Hum! 'tis very private, and I dare sin in private. A deuce take her, she revives, and prevents me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Where is the cruel Tyrant! inhumane Monster! but I will strive to fortifie my self. But Oh my misfortune! Oh my misery! Under what strange Enchantments am I bound? Could he be yet a thousand times more impious, I could not chuse but love his person still.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Be not so passionate; if you could be „Äà‚óä„Äâ, and love your self, I'd put you in a way to ease your grief now, and all your cares hereafter.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: If you can now ease an afflicted Woman, who else must shortly rid her self of life, imploy your charity; 'twas never plac'd yet on a Wretchneeded it more than I.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: If Loyalty in a Lover be a Jewel! say no more, I can tell you where you may have it‚Äî

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Speak not of truth in man, it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Pardon me, I speak on my own knowledge.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Is your Master true then? and have you happily deceiv'd me? Speak.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: As true as all the power of Hell can make him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: If he be false, let all the world be so.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: There's another-guess man than he, Madam.

lg.l: Another! who can that be?
No, no, there's no truth found in the Sex.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: He is a civil vertuous and discreet sober person.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Can there be such a man? what does he mean?

lg.l: There is, Madam, a man of goodly presence too‚Äî
Something inclining to be fat, of a round plump face, with quick and sparkling eyes, and mouth of cheerful overture‚Äî
His nose, which is the onely fault, is somewhat short, but that's no matter; his hair and eye-brows black, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: How! he may perhaps be brib'd by some other man, and what he said of his Master may be false.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: How she surveys me! Fa-la-la

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Who is this you speak of?

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: A man, who, envy must confess, has excellent parts, but those are gifts, gifts‚Äî meer gifts‚Äî thanks be to Heav'n for them.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But shall I never know his name?

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: He's one, whom many Ladies have honour'd with their affection; but no more of that. They have met disdain, and so forth. But he'll be content to marry you. Fa-la-la-la

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Again I ask you who he is?

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Lord, how inapprehensive she is? Can you not guess?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yours, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: It is my self in person; and upon my honour, I will be true and constant to you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Insolent Varlet! am I faln so low to be thy scorn?

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Scorn! as I am a Christian Soul, I am in earnest.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Audacious Villain! Impudence it self!

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Ah, Madam‚ñ™ your Servant, your true Lover must endure a thousand such bobs from his Mistris; I can bear, Madam, I can.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Because thy Master has betray'd me, am I become so infamous?

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: 'Tis something hard, Madam, to preserve a good reputation in his company; I can scarce do't my self.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Am I so miserable to descend to his man?

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Descend, say you: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Now I perceive all's false which you have said of him. Farewell, you base ingrateful Fellow.

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: Hold, Madam, come in the morning and I will place you in the next room, where you shall over-hear our discourse. You'll soon discover the mistake, and find who 'tis that loves you. Retire, Madam, I hear some body coming.

div.stage: Enter Don John in the Street.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Let me see, here lives a Lady: I have seen Don Octavio haunting about this house, and making private signs to her. I never saw her face, but am resolv'd to enjoy her, because he likes her; besides, she's another Woman.
Antonio, welcome to our place of randezvous. Well, what game! what adventure!
Come, dear Lopez.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I have had a rare adventure.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: What, dear Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I saw at a Villa not far off, a grave mighty bearded Fool, drinking Lemonado with his Mistris; I mislik'd his face, pluck'd him by the Whiskers, pull'd all one side of his Beard off, fought with him, run him through the thigh, carri'd away his Mistris,
serv'd her in her kind, and then let her go.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Gallantly perform'd, like a brave Souldier in an Enemies Countrey: When they will not pay Contribution, you fight for Forrage.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Pox on't, I have been damnably unfortunate; I have neither beat man, nor lain with Woman to night, but faln in love most furiously: I dogg'd my new Mistris to her Lodging; she's Don Bernardo's Sister, and shall be my Punk.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I could meet with no willing Dame, but was fain to commit a Rape to pass away the time.

sp.speaker: D. Anto.
sp.p: Oh! a Rape is the joy of my heart; I love a Rape, upon my Clavis, exceedingly.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: But mine, my Lads, was such a Rape, it ought to be Registred; a noble and heroick Rape.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Ah! dear Don John!

sp.speaker: D. Anto.
sp.p: How was it?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: 'Twas in a Church, Boys.

sp.speaker: D. Anto.
sp.p: Ah! Gallant Leader!

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Renown'd Don John!

sp.speaker: D. Anto.
sp.p: Come, let's retire, you have done enough for once.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Not yet, Antonio, I have an Intrigue here.
Here are my Fidlers. Rank your selves close under this Window, and sing the Song I prepar'd.

lg.l: THou joy of all hearts, and delight of all eyes,
Nature's chief Treasure, and Beauty's chief Prize,
Look down, you'l discover,
Here's a faithful young vigorous Lover;
With a heart full as true,
As e'r languish'd for you;
Here's a faithful young vigorous Lover.
The Heart that was once a Monarch in's breast,
Is now your poor Captive, and can have no rest;
'Twill never give over,
But about your sweet bosom will hover.
Dear Miss, let it in,
By Heav'n 'tis no sin;
Here's a faithful young vigorous vigorous Lover.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Now Fidlers, be gone.

div.stage: [Window opens, Maria looks out, and flings a Paper down.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Retire, my Dear Octavia; read that Note. Adieu.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Good, she takes me for Octavio. I warrant you, Boys, I shall succeed in this adventure. Now my false Light assist me.

p.hi: Go from this Window, within eight minutes you shall be admitted to the Garden dore. You know the Sign.

sp.p: Ha! the Sign, Gad she lies, I know not the Sign.

sp.speaker: D. Anto.
sp.p: What will you do? you know not the Sign. Let's away, and be contented this night.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: My friends, if you love me, retire. I'll venture, though Thunderbolts should fall upon my head.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Are you mad? as soon as she discovers the deceit, she'll raise the house upon you, and you'll be murder'd.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: She'll not raise the house for her own sake, but rather grant me all I ask to keep her counsell.

sp.speaker: D. Anto.
sp.p: 'Tis very dangerous: be care‚óè‚Ä¶al of your self.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: The more danger, the more delight: I hate the common road of pleasure. What! can I fear at such a time as this! The cowardly Deer are valiant in their Rutting time. I say, Be gone‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Anto.
sp.p: We'll not dispute your commands. Good luck to you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: How shall I know this devillish‚ñ™ Sign?
sp.stage: Enter Octavio with Fidlers, and stands under Maria's window.
sp.p: Ha! whom have we hear? some Serenading Coxcomb. Now shall we have some damn'd Song or other, a Cloris, or a Phillis at least.

lg.l: When you disperse your influence,
Your dazling Beams are quick and clear,
You so surprize and wound the sense,
So bright a Miracle y'appear.
Admiring Mortals you astonish so,
No other Deity they know,
But think that all Divinity's be low‚Äî
One charming look from your illustrious Face,
Were able to subdue Mankind,
So sweet, so powerful a Grace
Makes all men Lovers but the blind:
Nor can they freedom by resistance gain,
For each embraces the soft Chain,
And never struggles with the pleasant pain.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Be gone! be gone! the Window opens.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! this is Octavio. I must dispatch him, or he'll spoil all; but I would fain hear the Sign first.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What strange mistake is this? Sure he did not receive‚ñ™ my Note, and then I am ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: She expects the Sign. Where's my Whistle? O here.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I have found it, that must be the Sign‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I dare not speak aloud, go to the Garden door.
sp.stage: [Don John rushes upon Octavio, and snatches the Whistle out of his hand.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, what Ruffian's this?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: One that will be sure to cut your throat.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Make not a promise to your self of what you cann't perform.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I warrant you. Have at you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O Heav'n! Octavio's fighting. Oh my heart!

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Oh! I am slain‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I knew I should be as good as my word. I think you have it, Sir‚Äî Ha! „Äà‚óä„Äâ he's dying‚Äî Now for the Lady‚Äî I'll draw him further off, that his groans may not disturb our pleasure‚Äî Stay‚Äî by your leave, Sir, I'll change Hat and Cloak with you, it may help me in my design.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: O barbarous Villain!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: They have done fighting, and I hear no noise. Oh unfortunate Woman! my dear Octavio's kill'd‚Äî

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Perhaps, Madam, he has kill'd the other. I'll down to the Garden door; if he be well, he'll come thither, as well to satisfie his appointment, as to take refuge. Your Brother's safe, he may come in securely‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Haste! haste! Fly! fly! Oh Octavio. I'll follow her.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Now for the Garden door. This Whistle will do me excellent service. Now good luck‚Äî

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Octavio?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Heav'n be prais'd, my Lady thought you had been kill'd.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I am unhurt: let's quickly to her.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Oh! he'll be over-joy'd to see you alive.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I'll make her more over-joy'd before I have done with her. This is a rare adventure!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Here's your Jewel, Madam, speak softly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O my dear Octavio! have I got you within these arms?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Ay, my Dear, unpierc'd by any thing but by your eyes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Those will do you no hurt. But are you sure you are not wounded?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I am. Let me embrace my pretty Dear; and yet she may be a Blackamore for ought I know‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: We'll retire to my Chamber. Flora, go out, and prepare us a Collation.

sp.speaker: D. Jon.
sp.p: O admirable adventure! Come, my Delight.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Where's my pious Master?

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: We left him hereabouts. I wonder what he has done in his adventure: I believe he has had some busle.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: I thought I heard fighting hereabout.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Gad forgive me! fighting! where! where!

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: O thou incorrigible Coward!

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: See, here's some of his handy-work‚ñ™ here's a man kill'd‚ñ™

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Another murder. Heav'n, what will become of me? I shall be hang'd, yet dare not run away from him.

div.stage: Enter an Officer with a Guard, going the Round.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Stand! who are there?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: We do stand, Rascal, we never use to run.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Now shall I be taken and hang'd for my Master's murder.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Stand, you Dog! offer once more to run, and I'll put Bilbow in your guts.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Gad forgive me! what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: What's here? a man murder'd? yield, you are my prisoners.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: With all my heart! but as I hope to be sav'd, we did not kill him, Sir

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.p: These must be the murderers, disarm 'em.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: How now, Rascal! disarm us!

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: We are not us'd to part with our Swords.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I care not a farthing for my Sword, 'tis at your service.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Do you hear, Rascal; keep it, and fight, or I'll swear the murder against you.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Offer to flinch, and I'll run you through.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.p: Take their Swords, or knock 'em down.
sp.stage: [They fight. Jacomo offers to run, some of the Guards stop him.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: A pox on't, I had as good fight and die, as be taken and be hang'd.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Are you gone, you Dogs? I have pinck'd some of you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ah Rogues! Villains! I have met with you.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: O brave Jacomo! you fought like an imprison'd Rat: The Rogue had conceal'd Courage, and did not know it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O Cowards! Rascals! a man can get no honour by fighting with such Poletroons! but for all that, I will prudently withdraw, this place will suddenly be too hot for us.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Once in your life you are in the right, Jacomo.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O good Sir, there is as much to be ascribed to Conduct, as to Courage, I assure you.

div.stage: Enter Don John and Maria in her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Speak softly, my Dear; should my Brother hear us, we are ruin'd.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Though I can scarce contain my joy, I will. O she's a rare Creature in the dark, pray Heav'n she be so in the light.

div.stage: Enter Flora with a Candle; as soon as they discover Don John, they shreike out.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O Heav'n! I am ruin'd and betray'd.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: He has Octavio's clothes on.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O he has murder'd him. My Brother shall revenge it.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I will cut his throat if he offers it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thieves! Murder! Murder! Thieves!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Thieves! Murder! Murder! Thieves!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I will stop your shrill wind-pipes.

div.stage: „Äà‚óä„Äâ Maria's Brother, with his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! a man in my Sister's Chamber! Have at you, Villain.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come on, Villain.

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.p: Murder! Murder!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O Villain, thou hast kill'd my Brother, and dishonour'd me.
sp.stage: Enter five or six Servants, with drawn Swords.
sp.p: O your Master's murder'd!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: So many of you; 'tis no matter: your Hero's in Plays beat five times as many. Have at you, Rogues.
sp.stage: [Maria runs away shrieking, and Don John beats the Servants off, and stops Flora.
sp.p: Now give me the Key of the Garden, or I'll murder thee.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Murder! Murder! There, take it‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: So, thus far it is well; this was a brave adventure. 'Mongst all the Joys which in the world are sought, None are so great as those by dangers bought.

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: WHat will this leud Master of mine do? this Town of Sevil will not much care for his company after his last „Äà‚óä„Äâ Atchievments: He must now either fly, or hang for't. Ha! me-thinks my bloud grows chill at the naming of that dreadful word, Hang What will become of me? I dare not leave him, and yet I fear that I shall perish with him. He's certainly the sirst that ever set up a Religion to the Devil.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I come to claim your promise; is Don John within?

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.p: No, Madam, but I expect him every minute. You see, Madam, what honour I have for you, for I venture my ears to do this.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You oblige me extremely; so great is the present pain of doubt, that we desire to lose it: though in exchange of certainty, that must afflict us more.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I hear him coming, withdraw quickly.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: How now, Sir, what wise thoughts have you in your Noddle?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I was considering how well I could endure to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: And why so, Buffle?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why you will force me to wait upon you in all your fortunes, and you are making what haste you can to the Gallows‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Again at your reproofs. You insipid Rascal; I shall cut your ears off, Dog‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Good Sir, I have done; yet I cannot but admire, since you are resolv'd to go to the Devil, that you cannot be content with the common way of travelling, but must ride post to him.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Leave off your idle tales, found out by Priests to keep the Rabble in awe.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh horrid wickedness! If I may be bold to ask, what noble exploits did your Chivalry perform last night?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I committed a Rape upon my Father's Monument.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh horror!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Do you start, you Villain? Hah!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I, Sir, who I, Sir? not I, Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p:
D'hear, Rascal, let me not see a frown upon your
face; if I do, I will cut your throat, you Rogue.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, Sir, no, Sir, I warrant you; I am in a very good humour, I assure you‚Äî Heav'n deliver me!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Now listen and learn. I kill'd a Lady's Lover, and suppli'd his place, by stratagem enjoy'd her: In came her foolish Brother and surpriz'd me, but perish'd by mv hand; and I doubt not but I maul d three or four of his Servants.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh horrid fact!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Again, Villain, are you frowning?

sp.speaker: „Äà‚óä„Äâ.
sp.p: No, Sir, no, Sir; don't think so ill of me, Sir. Heav'n send me from this wicked Wretch! What will become of us, Sir? we shall be apprehended.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Can you fear your Rascally Carcase, when I venture mine? I observe always, those that have the most despicable persons, are most careful to preserve 'em.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your pardon; but I have an odd humour, makes me something unsit for your Worship's service.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: What's that, Sirra?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: 'Tis a very odd one, I am almost asham'd to tell it to you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Out with it, Fool‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why Sir, I cannot tell what is the reason, but I have a most unconquerable antipathy to Hemp. I could never endure a Bell-rope. Hanging is a kind of death I cannot abide, I am not able to endure it.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I have taken care to avoid that; my friends are gone to hire a Vessel, and we'll to Sea together to seek a refuge, and a new Scene of pleasure.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: All three, Sir?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Three as civil discreet sober persons, as a man wou'd wish to drink with.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I can hold no longer!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, you Dog, how came she here?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I don't know, Sir, she stole in‚Äî

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What Witchcraft do I suffer under? that when I abhor his vices, I still love his person. Ah, Don John! have I deserv'd that you should fly me? are all your Oaths and Vows forgotten by you?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: No, no; in these cases I always remember my Oaths, and never forget to break them.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh impiety!

Did I, for this, yield up my Honour to you? after you had sigh'd and languish'd many moneths, and shew'd all signs of a sincere affection, I trusted in your truth and constancy, without the Bond of Marriage, yielded up a Virgin's Treasure, all my Innocence, believ'd your solemn Contract, when you invok'd all the Pow'rs above to testifie your Vows.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: They think much of us, why don't they witness 'em for you‚Äî Pish, 'tis nothing but a way of speaking, which young amorous Fellows have gotten‚Äî

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Did you not love me then? What injury had I e'r done you, that you shou'd feign affection to betray me?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Yes 'faith, I did love you, and shew'd you as frequent and as hearty signs of it as I could; and i'gad y'are an ungrateful Woman if you say the contrary.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: O heav'n! Did you, and do not now? What crime have I committed, that could make you break your Vows and Oaths, and banish all your passion? Ah! with what tenderness have I receiv'd your feign'd affection, and ne'r thought I liv'd but in your presence; my love was too fervent to be counterfeit‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: That I know not, for since your Sex are such dissemblers, they can hold out against, and seem to hate the men they love; why may they not seem to love the men they hate?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: O cruel man! could I dissemble? had I a thousand lives, I ventur'd all each time I saw your face; nay, were I now discover'd, I should instantly be sacrific'd to my raging Brother's fury; and can I dissemble?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I do not know whether you do or no; you see I don't, I am something free with you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: And do you not love me then?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p:
Faith, Madam, I lov'd you as long as I could for the
heart and bloud of me, and there's an end of it; what a Devil wou'd you have more?

sp.speaker: „Äà‚óä„Äâ.
sp.p: O cruel man! how miserable have you made me!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Miserable! use variety as I do, and you'll not be „Äà‚óä„Äâ. Ah! there's nothing so sweet to frail humane flesh „Äà‚óä„Äâ variety.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: inhumane Creature! what have I been guilty of, that thou shouldst thus remove thy „Äà‚óä„Äâ from me?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Guilty, no: but I have had enough of you, and I have done what I can for you, and there's no more to be said.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Tigers would have more pity than thou hast.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Unreasonable Woman! would you have a man love „Äà‚óä„Äâ enjoyment? I think the Devil's in you‚Äî

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Do you upbraid me with the rash effects of Love, which you caus'd in me? and do you hate me for what you ought to love me for? were you not many moneths with Vows and Oaths betraying me to that weakness? Ungrateful Monster!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Why the Devil did you not yield before? you Women always rook in Love; you'll never play upon the square with us..

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: False man! I yielded but too soon. Unfortunate Woman!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Your dissembling Arts and jilting tricks, taught you by your Mothers, and the phlegmatick coldness of your constitutions, make you so long in yielding; that we love out almost all our love before you begin, and yet you would have our love last as long as yours. I got the start of you a long way, and have reason to reach the Goal before you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Did you not swear you wou'd for ever love me?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Why there 'tis; why did you put me to the trouble to swear it? If you Women would be honest, and follow the Dictates of Sense and Nature, we shou'd agree about the business presently, and never be forsworn for the matter.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Are Oaths so slighted by you? perfidious man!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Oaths! Snares to catch conceited Women with; I wou'd have sworn all the Oathes under the Sun; why I wou'd have committed Treason for you, and yet I knew I should be weary of you‚Äî

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I thought such love as mine might have deserv'd your constancy, false and ungrateful man!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Thus your own vanity, not we betray you. Each woman thinks, though men are false to others, that she is so fine a person, none can be so to her. You should not take our words of course in earnest.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Thus Devils do in Hell, who cruelly upbraid whom they have tempted thither.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: In short, my constitution will not let me love you longer: and what ever some „Äà‚óä„Äâ pretend, all mankind obey their constitutions, and cannot do otherwise‚Äî

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Heav'n, sure, will punish this vile treachery.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Do you then leave it to Heav'n, and trouble your self no farther about it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Ye Sacred Pow'rs, who take care of injur'd innocence, assist me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Sir, Sir! stand upon your guard.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: How now! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Here's a whole Batalion of couragious Women come to charge you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: 'em out, you Villain.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I cannot, they over-run me.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: What an inundation of Strumpets is here?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: O Heav'n! I can stay no longer to be a witness of his falshood‚Äî

sp.speaker: 1. Wom.
sp.p: My Dear, I desire a word in private with you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: 'Faith, my Dear, I am something busie, but I love thee dearly.

sp.speaker: 2. Wom.
sp.p: Don John, a word: 'tis time now we should declare our marriage; 'tis now above three weeks.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Ay, we will do it suddenly‚Äî

sp.speaker: 3. Wom.
sp.p:
Pre'thee, Honey, what bus'ness can these idle Women
have‚ñ™ send them packing, that we may confer about our „Äà‚óä„Äâ.

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: Lord! how am I amaz'd at the confidence of some Women! who are these that will not let one converse with one's own Husband? By your leave, Ladies.

sp.speaker: „Äà‚óä„Äâ.
sp.p: Now it works! tease him, Ladies, worry him soundly‚Äî

sp.speaker: 5. Wom.
sp.p: Nay, by your leave, good Madam; if you go to that.

sp.speaker: 6. Wom.
sp.p: Ladies, by all your leaves; sure none of you will have the confidence to pretend an interest in this Gentleman‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I shall be torn in pieces: Jacomo, stand by me.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Lord, Madam, what's your meaning? none ought to claim a right to another Woman's Husband, let me tell you that.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: You are in the right, Madam. Therefore prethee, Dear, let's withdraw, and leave them; I do not like their company.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Ay, presently, my Dear. What an excellent thing is a Woman before enjoyment, and how insipid after it!

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: Come, prethee, put these Women out of doubt, and let them know our Marriage.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Tomorrow we'll declare and celebrate our Nuptials.

sp.speaker: 6. Wom.
sp.p: Ladies, the short and the long on't is, you are very uncivil to press upon this Gentleman. Come, Love, e'en tell 'em the truth of the story‚Äî

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: Uncivil, Madam, pardon me; one cannot be so in speaking to one's own.

sp.speaker: 3. Wom.
sp.p: That's true; she little thinks who that is.

sp.speaker: 6. Wom.
sp.p: To their own! Ha, ha, ha, that's true‚Äî Come, Honey, keep 'em no longer in ignorance.

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: Come, Ladies, I will undeceive you all; think no further of this Gentleman, I say, think no further of him‚Äî

sp.speaker: 1. Wom.
sp.p: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Hold, for Heav'n's sake; you know not what you do.

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I do; it shall all out: I'll send 'em away with Fleas in their Ears. Poor silly Creatures!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Now will Civil Wars arise‚Äî

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: Trouble your selves no longer about Don John, he is mine‚Äî he is mine, Ladies‚Äî

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Yours!‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Pox on't, I must set a good face upon the bus'ness; I see murder will out‚Äî

sp.speaker: 6 Wom.
sp.p: Yours! that's pleasant; he's mine‚Äî

sp.speaker: 5. Wom.
sp.p: I have been too long patient; he is my Husband.

sp.speaker: 1. Wom.
sp.p: Yours, how can that be? I am sure I am his Wife.

sp.speaker: 3. Wom.
sp.p: Are you not „Äà‚óä„Äâ, Ladies, to claim my Husband?

sp.speaker: 2. Wom.
sp.p: Are you all mad? I am sure I am marri'd to him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Look you, Ladies, a Man's but a Man; here's my Body, tak't among you as far as 'twill go. The Devil cann't please you all‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Pray, Ladies, will you dispatch; for there are a matter of fifteen more that are ready to put in their claims, and must be heard in their order‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: How now, Rogne? this is your fault, Sirra.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: My fault, Sir, no; the Ladies shall see I am no Traitor. Look you, Ladies‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Peace, Villain, or I will cut your throat. Well, Ladies, know then, I am marri'd to one in this company; and to morrow morning, if you will repair to this place, I will declare my Marriage, which now, for some secret Reasons, I am oblig'd to conceal‚Äî Now will each Strumpet think 'tis her I mean.

sp.speaker: 1. Wom.
sp.p: That's well enough.

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: I knew he would own me at last.

sp.speaker: 3. Wom.
sp.p: Now they will soon see their errors.
5. Now we'll conceal it no longer, Dearest.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: No, no, I warrant you‚Äî

sp.speaker: 6. Wom.
sp.p: Lord how blank these Ladies will look.

sp.speaker: 2. Wom.
sp.p: Poor Ladies‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ladies, pray let me ask a question, which of you is really marri'd to him?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: I, I, I‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p:
'Sdeath, you Son of a Baboon. Come, Pox on't, why should I dally any longer! why should I conceal my good actions! in one word, I am married to every one of you, and have
above fourscore more; nor will I ever give over, till I have as many Wives and Concubines as the Grand Seignior.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: A very modest civil person truly‚Äî

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: O horrid Villain!

sp.speaker: 6. Wom.
sp.p: Perfidious Monster!

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: How now, Don John; Hah! you are a rav'nous Bird of prey indeed; do you fly at no less than a whole Covee of Whores at once? you scorn a single Strumpet for your Quarry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What, in tears too! Fie, Don John; thou art the most ungentle Knight alive: use your Ladies civilly for shame.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Ay, before the Victory, I grant you; but after it, they should wear Chains, and follow the Conqueror's Chariot.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Alas, poor Harlots!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Peace, peace, good words; these are certain Animals call'd Wives, and all of 'em are my Wives: Do you call a man of Honour's Wives, Harlots? out, on't.

sp.speaker: 1. Wom.
sp.p: Perfidious Monster!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come on, you are come very opportunely, to help to celebrate my several and respective Weddings. Come, my Dears; 'faith we will have a Ballad at our Weddings. Where are my Fidlers?

sp.speaker: 6. Wom.
sp.p: O salvage Beast!

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: Inhumane Villain! revenge shall follow.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Pox on revenge. Call in my Ministrils.
Come, sing my Epithalamium.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: SInce Liberty, Nature for all has design'd,
Apox on the Fool who to one is confin'd.
All Creatures besides,
When they please change their Brides.
All Females they get when they can,
Whilst they nothing but Nature obey,
How happy, how happy are they?
But the silly fond Animal, Man,
Makes Laws 'gainst himself, which his Appetites sway;
Poor Fools, how unhappy are they?
Since Liberty, Nature for all has design'd,
Apox on the Fool who to one is confin'd.
At the first going down, a Woman is good,
But when e'er she comes up, I'll ne'r chew the Cud,
But out she shall go,
And I'll serve 'em all so.
When with one my stomach is cloy'd,
Another shall soon be enjoy'd.
Then how happy, how happy are we?
Let the Coxcomb, when weary, drudge on,
And foolishly stay when he wou'd fain be gone.
Poor Fool! how unhappy is he?

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: At the first going down, &c.

lg.l: Let the Rabble obey, I'll live like a Man,
Who, by Nature, is free to enjoy all he can:
Wise Nature does teach
More truth than Fools preach;
They bindus, but she gives us ease.
I'll revel and love where I please.
She, she's my infallible Guide.
But were the bless'd freedom deni'd
Of variety in the things we love best,
Dull Man were the slavishest Beast.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: Let the Rabble obey, &c.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come, how do you like this? let's be merry, my Brides.

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: O monstrous Traitor! do you mock our misery?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Good Spouse, be not passionate‚Äî faith we'll have a Dance. Strike up‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Be comforted, good Ladies; you have Companions in your misfortunes‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: He has been marri'd in all the Cities of Spain; what a breed of Don Johns shall we have?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come, Sweethearts; you must be civil to these Gentlemen; they are my Friends, and men of Honour‚ñ™

sp.speaker: 6. Wom.
sp.p: Men of Honour! they are Devils if they be your‚ñ™ Friends.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I hate unreasonable, unconscionable fellows, who when they are weary of their Wives, will still keep 'em from other men. Gentlemen, ye shall command mine.

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: Thinkest thou I will out-live this affront?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I'll trust you for that, there's ne'r a Lucrece now adays, the Sex has learnt more wit since. Let me see, Antonia, thou shalt have for thy present use, let me see, my sixth Wife‚Äî‚ñ™ faith she's a pretty buxom Wench, and deserves hearty usage from thee.

sp.speaker: 6. Wom.
sp.p: Traitor! I'll be reveng'd on all thy treachery.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A mettel'd Girl, I like her well: she'll endure a Rape gallantly. I love resistance, it endears the pleasure.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: And, Lopez, thou shalt have, let me see, ay, my fourth Spouse, she's a brave Virago; and Gad if I had not been something familiar with her already, I would venture my life for her.

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: Vile Wretch! think'st thou I will out-live this affront? Impious Villain! though thou hast no sense of Vertue or Honour left, thou shalt find I have.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Vertue and Honour! There's nothing good or ill, but as it seems to each man's natural appetite, if they will consent freely. You must ravish friends: that's all I know, you must ravish.

sp.speaker: 1. Wom.
sp.p: Unheard of Villany! Fly from this Hellish place.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ladies, you shall fly, but we must ravish first.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Yes, I assure you we must ravish‚Äî

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: No, Monster, I'll prevent you.

lg.l: 'Sdeath, she's as good as her word.
The first time I e'r knew a Woman so.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Pox on't, she has prevented me; she's dead.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Say you so? well, go thy ways, thou wer't a Girl of pretty parts, that's the truth on't; but I ne'r thought this had been in thee.

sp.speaker: 2. Wom.
sp.p: These, sure, are Devils in the shape of men.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Now see my providence, if I had been marri'd to none but her, I had been a Widdower.

sp.speaker: 1. Wom.
sp.p: O horror! horror! flie! flie!

sp.speaker: 6. Wom.
sp.p: No, I'll be reveng'd first on this barbarous Wretch.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Why look you, here's a Wench of mettle for you; go ravish quickly‚Äî

sp.speaker: 6. Wom.
sp.p: Let's fly, and call for help, some in the street may help us‚ñ™
sp.stage: [They all run off, crying, Help, murder, murder!

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Let 'em go, they are confin'd, they cann't get out.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: It shall ne'r be said that a Woman went out of this house Reinfecta; but after that, 'twill be time for us to fly.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: We have hir'd a Vessel, the Master is a brave Rogue of my acquaintance; he has been a Bandit.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: A brave honest wicked Fellow as heart can wish, I have ravish'd, robb'd, and murder'd with him.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: That's well. Hey, where are my Rogues? Hey!
Here, Sirra, do you send my Goods on Board.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My Man will direct you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come, Sirra, do you remove this Body to another Room‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O horrid fact! what, another Murder! what shall I do?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Leave your complaints, you Dog; I'll send you after her.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! I shall be hang'd, I shall be hang'd.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Take her up, Rascal; or I'll cut your throat.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I will, Sir. Oh mercy upon me! I shall be hang'd‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Now, Sirra, do you run into the streets, and force in the next Woman you meet, or I'll cut your Wind-pipe; and let nobody out‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What hellish fact will he now commit?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Take her up, you Hen-hearted compassionate Rascal.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Heav'n! what will become of me? Oh! Oh‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Now, Gentlemen, you shall see I'll be civil to you, you shall not ravish alone: indeed I am loath to meddle with mine old acquaintance, but if my Man can meet with a Woman I have not lain withall, I'll keep you company; let her be old or young, ugly or handsome, no matter.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: 'Faith I will eversay, you are a well bred man.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: A very civil person, a man of Honour.

div.stage: Enter Servant, forcing in an ugly old Woman, who cries out.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: This unlucky Rogue has made but a scurvy choice, but I'll keep my word. Come, Bawd, you must be ravish'd, Bawd.

sp.speaker: Old. Wom.
sp.p: O murder! murder! help! help! I was never ravish'd in my life.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: That I dare swear; but to show I am a very vigorous man, I'll begin with you. But, you Rascal, Jaccall, I'll make you Cater better next time.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, this was the first I met.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come on, Beldam, thy face shall not protect thee.

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.p: Oh my Honour! my Honour! help, help, my Honour!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come to our business.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O Sir‚ñ™ „Äà‚óä„Äâ! shift for your self; we shall all be hang'd: „Äà‚óä„Äâ house is „Äà‚óä„Äâ. Oh what shall we do?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p:
Away, Coward: were the King of Spain's Army beleagu'ring
us, it should not divert me from this Exploit.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Nor me.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Nor me: let's on.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Keep the doors fast, Sirra. Come on.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh what will become of me! Oh Heav'n! mercy on me! Oh! Oh!

div.stage: In Man's habit, Enter Maria, and her Maid Flora.

lg.l: Thus I have abandon'd all my Fortune, and laid by
My Sex. Revenge for thee. Assist me now,
You Instruments of Bloud, for my dear Brothers,
And for my much more dear Octavio's sake.
Where are my Bravo's?‚Äî
They have beset the Villains House,
And he shall ne'r come out alive.‚Äî
O let 'em show no more remorse,
Than hungry Lions o'r their prey will.
How miserable am I made by that
Inhumane Monster! No savage Beast,
Wild Deserts e'r brought forth, provok'd
By all its hunger, and its natural rage,
Could yet have been so cruel.
Oh my Octavio! whether art thou fled,
From the most loving and most wretched
Creature of her Sex? What Ages of delight
Each hour with thee brought forth!
How much, when I had thee, was all the world
Unenvi'd by me! Nay, I piti'd all my Sex,
That cou'd have nothing worth their care,
Since all the treasure of Mankind was mine.
Methought I cou'd look down on Queens, when he
Was with me: but now, compar'd to me,
How happy is the Wretched, whose sinews
Crack upon the merciless Engine
Of his torture? I live with greater torments then he did.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Leave your complaints. Tears are no Sacrifice for bloud.

lg.l: Now my just grief to just revenge give place.
I am asham'd of these soft Tears, till I've
Reveng'd thy horrid Murder. Oh that I could
Make the Villain linger out an Age in
Torments! But I will revel in his bloud: Oh
I could suck the last drop that warms the
Monster's heart, that might inspire me with
Such cruelty, as vile Man, with all his horrid
Arts of power, is yet a stranger to;
Then I might root out all his cursed Race.
I'll follow all your Fortunes, my dear Lady;
Had „Äà‚óä„Äâ thousand lives, in this cause I'd
Venture one by one to my last stake.
Thou art my dear and faithful Creature;
Let not thy Fortunes thus be wrack'd with mine.
Be gone, and leave thy most unhappy Mistris;
One that has miseries enow to sink the Sex.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I will not leave you, till death takes me from you.

lg.l: O that I had been some poor lost Mountain Girl,
Nurs'd up by Goats, or suckl'd by wild Beasts,
Expos'd to all the rage of heats and killing colds.
I ne'r could have been aband on'd to such fury.
More savage cruelty reigns in Cities,
Than ever yet in Desarts among the
Most venomous Serpents, and remorsless
Ravenous Beasts, could once be found.
So much has barb'rous Art debauch'd
Man's innocent Nature.
Lay by your tears, till your revenge be finish'd;
Then, then you may have leisure to complain.
I will: 'tis bloud I now must spill, or
Lose my own in th'attempt. But if I can
Have the fortune, with my own hand, to reach
The Dogs vile heart: I then shall die
Contented, and in the other World I'll
„Äà‚óä„Äâ him so, Devils shall learn of me to
Else the Damn'd.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Let's to our Sacred Instruments of revenge.

lg.l: Come on: so just a cause would turn the
Vilest Ruffian to a Saint.
Come, friends, let once a Woman preach courage
To you, inspir'd by my just rage this Arm
Shall teach you wonders. I'll shew you now
What Love with just Revenge can do.
We are so practis'd in the trade of death,
We need no teaching.
There's Gold good store; if you dispatch the Dog,
I'll give you yet much more; if not,
If all the wealth I have can buy your lives,
I'll have 'em in stead of his.

sp.speaker: 1. Brav.
sp.p: For half the Sum, I'd kill a Bishop at th' Altar.

div.stage: Enter Don John, Don Antonio, Don Lopez, Jacomo.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Now we have finish'd our design; let's make a Salley, and raise the Siege.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Jacomo, do you lead the Van.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Lead on, Jacomo, or we are sure to lose you; you are not good at bringing up the Rear.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Nay, good Gentlemen, I know my self better than to take place of Men of Quality, especially upon this occasion.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Sirra, go on: I'll prick him forward. Remember, if you do not fight, I am behind you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh Heav'n! Oh Jacomo! what will become of thy dear person? Is this your Courage to put me forward, to what you dare not meet your selves?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: No words, Rogue, on, on, I say‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O I shall be murder'd! murder'd! Oh! Oh!‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: On, on, you Dog.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Inhumane Master! It must be so! Heav'n have mercy on my better part.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fall on, fall on, that's the Villain! Have at you, Dog‚ñ™

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Courage, Jacomo.
sp.stage: [They fight, and are driven off, but Maria and Flora remain.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh cowardly Villains! the Traitor will escape their hands. Oh Dogs! more feeble than the feeblest of our Sex Let's after him, and try our strength.
He is return'd‚Äî fall on.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Ha! must I encounter Boys?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Oh I am slain‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: At thy heart, base Villain.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: There, take your Sword; I'll not nip Roguery in the bud; thou may'st live to be as wicked as my self.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Poor Flora! But, Dog, I'll be reveng'd on thee yet ere I die.

div.stage: Enter Don Lopez, Don Antonio, Jacomo.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What! no thanks! no reward!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: What's the matter, Sirra?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What, no acknowledgment? you are but an ungrateful man, let me tell you that, to treat a man of my prowess thus.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: What has your valour done?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing; sav'd your life onely, that's all: but men of valour are nothing now adays. 'Tis an ungrateful Age. I fought like a Hero

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Call'd a Stag at Bay.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: You can fight, when there's no way of escape, without it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! what's here! another murder! fly, fly; we shall be hang'd.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come on! let's now to Sea to try our fortunes.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, make haste; I've laid Horses, and will shift by Land. Farewell, Sir; a good Voyage‚Äî‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I will murder you, if you refuse to go to Sea‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O, good Sir, consider, do but consider; I am so Sea-sick always: that wicked Element does not agree with me.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Dare you dispute! go on, I say.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O, good Sir, think, think a little; the merciless Waves will never consider a man of parts: besides, Sir, I can swim no more than I can fly.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I'll leave you dead upon the place, if you refuse.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O Sir, on my knees I beg you'll let me stay. I am the last of all my Family; my Race will fail, if I should fail.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Damn your Race‚ñ™

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Do not we venture with you?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: You have nothing but your lives to venture, but I have a whole Family to save; I think upon Posterity. Besides, Gentlemen, I can look for no safety in such wicked company.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I'll kill the Villain. His fear will else betray us.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O hold! hold! for Heav'ns sake hold‚ñ™

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.p: Hold! hold!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, hold, hold. Oh Heav'n! your Father's Ghost; a Ghost! a Ghost! Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! what's here? my Father alive!

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.p: No, no; inhumaue Murderer, I am dead.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: That's well; I was afraid the old Gentleman had come for his Estate again; if you wou'd have that, 'tis too late; 'tis spent‚Äî

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.p: Monster! Behold these wounds.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I do; they were well meant, and well perform'd, I see.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: This is strange! how I am amaz'd!

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Unheard of Wonder!‚Äî

lg.l: Repent, repent of all thy villanies;
My clamorous blood to Heav'n for vengeance cries.
Heav'n will pour out his judgments on you all;
Hell gapes for you, for you each Fiend does call,
And hourly waits your unrepenting fall.
You with eternal horrours they'l torment,
Except of all your crimes you suddenly repent.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! Heav'n deliver me from these Monsters.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Farewell, thou art a foolish Ghost; Repent, quoth he! what could this mean? our senses are all in a mist sure.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: They are not, 'twas a Ghost.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: I ne'r believ'd those foolish Tales before.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come, 'tis no matter; let it be what it will, it must be natural‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: And Nature is unalterable in us too.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: 'Tis true, the nature of a Ghost cannot change ours.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: It was a silly Ghost, and I'll no sooner take his word than a Whores.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Thou art in the right. Come, Fool, Fool, rise; the Ghost is gone.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! I die, I die; pray let me die in quiet.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Oh! if he be dying‚ñ™ take him up; we'll give him burial in the Sea. Come on.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Gentlemen; bury me not till I am dead, I beseech you‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: If you be not, Sirra, I'll run you through.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, I'll go, I'll go‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Let's on.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Let's on.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Should all the Bugbears Cowards feign appear, I would urge on without one thought of fear.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: And I.‚Äî

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Enter Don John, Don Lopez, Don Antonio, Jacomo, Captain of the Ship, Master and Sailors.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: MErcy upon us! what sudden dreadful storm is this? we are all lost; we shall split upon the Rocks. Loof, loof‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! Mercy! Oh I was afraid of this! See what your wickedness has brought me to? Mercy! mercy!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Takeaway thy Cowardly face, it offends me, Rascal.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Such dreadful claps of Thunder I never yet remember'd.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Let the Clowds roar on, and vomit all their Sulphur out, they ne'r shall fright me.‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: These are the Squibs and Crackers of the Sky.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Fire on, fire on; we are unmov'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The Heav'ns are all on sire; these unheard of Prodigies amaze me.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Can you, that have stood so many Cannons, be frighted at the farting and the belching of a Clowd?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: Bless me, Captain! six of our Foremast men are even now struck dead with Lightning.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: O that clap has rent our Masts in sunder.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O we are lost! You can swim, Sir; pray save me, Sir, for my own and Family's sake.‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Toss these cowardly Rogues over-board. Captain, Courage! let the Heav'ns do their worst, 'tis but drowning at laft.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: But‚Äî in the name of Heav'n, but drowning, quoth he; your drowning will prepare you for burning, though Oh, Oh, Oh‚Äî

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Captain, Captain, the Ship's on fire in the Forecastle‚Äî

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: All hands to work upon the Forecastle. Heav'n! how it blazes already!‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! we burn, we drown, we sink, Oh! we perish, we are lost, we are lost. Oh, Oh, Oh‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: O horrid Apparitions! Devils stand and guard the fire, and will not suffer us to quench it. We are lost.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: In all the dangers I have been, such horrors I never knew; I am quite unmann'd.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: A man and fear: 'tis but dying at last.

sp.speaker: D‚ñ™ Joh.
sp.p: I never yet could know what that foolish thing Fear is.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Help, help, the fire increases. What horrid sights are these? where e'r I turn me, fearful Spirits appear.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Let's into the Boat, and with our Swords keep out all others.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: While they are busie 'bout the sire we may 'scape.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: If we get from hence, we certainly shall perish on the Rocks‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I warrant you‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O good Gentlemen, let us shift for our selves, and let the rest burn, or drown, and be damn'd and they will.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: No, you have been often leaving me: now shall be the time we'll part. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! I'll stand by you while I live. Oh the Devil, the Devil! What horrors do I feel? Oh I am kill'd, I am dead!
sp.stage: [A Thunder-clap strikes Don John and Jacomo down.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! why this to me? you paltry foolish bugbear Thunder, am I the mark of your sensless rage?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Nothing but accident. Let's leap into the Boat.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: The Sailors all make towards us; they'll in and sink it.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Sirra, if you come on, you run upon my Sword.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O cruel Tyrant! I burn, I drown, I sink! Oh I die, I am lost.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: All shift aboard; we perish, we are lost.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: All lost, all lost.
sp.stage: [A great shreik, they all leap over-board.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: This fourty years I've liv'd in this neighbouring Cave, and from these dreadful Cliffs which are always beaten by the foaming Surges of the Sea; beheld the Ocean in its wildestrage, and ne'r yet saw a storm so dreadful: such horrid flashes of lightning, and such claps of thunder, never were in my remembrance. Yon Ship is all on fire, and the poor miserable Wretches must all perish. The dreadful object melts my heart, and brings a floud of tears into my eyes: It is prodigious, for on the sudden, all the Heavens are clear again, and the inraged Sea is become more patient.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Oh Father, have you not been frighted at this prodigious storm, and at yon dreadful spectacle?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: No man that has an apprehension, but wou'd have been mov'd with horrour.

sp.speaker: D. Franc.
sp.p: 'T was the most violent Tempest I ever saw. Hold, yonder are some coming in a small Vessel, and must necessarily split upon the Rock; I'll go and help to succour 'em.

lg.l: Here are some this way, just come in a small Boat:
Go you to those, and these I will assist‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: I'll haste to their relief‚Äî

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Hah! these are come safe to Land, three men, goodly men they seem to be; I am bound in charity to serve them: they come towards me.

div.stage: Enter Don John, Don Antonio, and Don Lopez.

sp.speaker: D. Joh‚ñ™
sp.p: Much ado we are safe, but my Man's lost; pox on him, I shall miss the Fool, it was a necessary Blockhead.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: But you have lost your Goods, which were more necessary.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Our Jewels and Money we have all about us.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p:
It makes me laugh to think, how the Fools we left
behind were puzzl'd which death to chuse, burning or drowning‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: But how shall we dispose of our selves, we are plaguy wet and cold. Hah! what old Fool is that?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: It is an Hermit, a fellow of mighty Beard and Sanctity.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I know not what Sanctity he may have, but he has Beard enough to make an Owl's Nest, or stuff a Saddle with.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I see you are shipwrack'd, and in distress; and my Function obliges me in charity to succour you in what I may.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Alas! what canst thou help us to? dost thou know of ever a house near hand, where we may be furnished with some necessaries?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: On the other side of this vast Rock, there is a fertile and a pleasant Valley, where one Don Francisco, a rich and hospitable man, has a sweet Dwelling; he will entertain you nobly: He's gone to assist some shipwrack'd persons, and will be here presently. In the mean time, what my poor Cave can afford, you shall be welcome to.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: What can that afford? you oblige your self to fasting and abstinence‚ñ™

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: I have studi'd Physick for the relief of needy people, and I have some Cordials which will refresh you; I'll bring one to you‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: A good civil old Hipocrite: but this is a pleasant kind of Religion, that obliges 'em to nastiness and want of meat. I'll ha' none on't.‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: No, nor of any other, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Gentlemen, pray taste of this Vial, it will comfort your cold stomachs.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Ha! 'tis excellent 'faith. Let it go round.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Heav‚ñ™ n bless it to you.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Ha! it warms.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Thank thee, thou art a very honest old fellow i'faith.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p:
I see thou art very civil; but you must supply us
with one necessary more; a very necessary thing, and very refreshing.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: What's that, Sir?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: It is a Whore, a fine young buxom Whore.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: A Whore, Old man, a Whore.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: A Whore, Old man, a Whore.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Bless me, are you Men or Devils?‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Men, men, and men of lust and vigour. Pre'thee, old Sot, leave thy prating, and help me to a Strumpet, a fine salacious Strumpet; I know you Zealots have enough of 'em. Women love your godly Whore-masters.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: O Monsters of impiety! are you so lately scap'd the wrath of Heaven, thus to provoke it?

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
