sp.p: How! by following the Dictates of Nature, who can do otherwise?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: All our actions are necessitated, none command their own wills.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Oh horrid blasphemy! would you lay your dreadful and unheard of Vices upon Heaven? No, ill men, that has given you free-will to good.

lg.l: I find thou retir'st here, and never readst or thinkst.
Can that blind faculty the Will be free,
When it depends upon the Understanding?
Which argues first before the Will can chuse;
And the last Dictate of the Judgment sways
The Will, as in a Balance, the last Weight
Put in the Scale, lifts up the other end,
And with the same Necessity.
But foolish men and sinners act against
Their Understandings, which inform 'em better.
None willingly do any thing against the last
Dictates of their Judgments, whatsoe'r men do,
Their present opinions lead 'em to.
As fools that are afraid of sin, are by the thought
Of present pleasure, or some other reason,
Necessarily byass'd to pursue
The opinion they are of at that moment.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: The Understanding yet is free, and might perswade 'em better.

lg.l: The Understanding never can be free;
For what we understand, spite of our selves we do:
All objects are ready form'd and plac'd
To our hands; and these the Senses to the Mind convey,
And as those represent them, this must judge:
How can the Will be free, when the Understanding,
On which the Will depends, cannot be so.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Lay by your devillish Philosophy, and change the dangerous and destructive course of your leud lives.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Change our natures? Go bid a Blackamore be white, we follow our Constitutions, which we did not give our selves.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: What we are, we are by Nature, our reason tells us we must follow that.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Our Constitutions tell us one thing, and yours another; and which must we obey? If we be bad, 'tis Nature's fault that made us so.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Farewell. I dare no longer hear your impious discourse. Such harden'd Wretches I ne'r heard of yet.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Farewell, old Fool.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Thus Sots condemn what they can never answer.
This I believe is Francisco, whom he spoke of; if he has but a handsome Wife, or Daughters, we are happy.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Sir, we are shipwrack'd men, and if you can direct us to a place, where we may be furnish'd with some necessaries, you will oblige us‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Franc.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I have a House hard by, you shall be welcome to it: I even now endeavoured to succour a Youth and beauteous Woman, who, with two Sailors, in a Boat, were driven towards these Rocks, but were forc'd back again, and, I fear, are lost by this time. I desire nothing more, than to assist men in extremes, and am o'rjoy'd at the opportunity of serving you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: We thank you.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p:
You shall command my House as long as you please:
I see you are Cavaliers, and hope you will bear with some inconvenience. I have two young, and, though I say it, handsome Daughters, who are, to morrow morning to be marri'd; the Solemnity will bring much company together, which, I fear, may incommode my house and you‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: You pose us with this kindness.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: What ever pleases you, cannot be inconvenient to us.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: On the contrary, we shall be glad to assist you at the Ceremony, and help to make up the joyful Chorus.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: You shall command my house and me; I'll shew you the way to it‚ñ™

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Your humble Servant. We'll follow you.

lg.l: This is an admirable adventure.
He has Daughters, Boys, and to be marri'd too:
If they have been so foolish, to preserve those
Toys, they call Maidenheads; their sensless
Husbands shall not be troubled with them:
I'll ease them of those. Pox, what should those dull
Drudging Animals, call'd Husbands, do with such Treasures:
No, they are for honest Whore-masters, Boys.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Well said, Don; we will not be wanting in our endeavours to succeed you.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: To you alone we must give place. Allons.

div.stage: Enter Hermit, Maria in Man's habit, and Leonora.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Heaven be prais'd, you are safely now on Land.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: We thank you, reverend Father, for your assistance.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: We never shall forget the obligation.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: I am happy to be so good an Instrument.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: We follow'd a Vessel, which we saw fir'd with Lightning, and we fear that none of 'em escap'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I hope the Villain I pursue has scap'd. I would not be reveng'd by Heaven, but my own hand; or, if not by that, by the Hangman's.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Did any come to Land? for I most nearly am concern'd
or one; the grief for whom, if he belost, will soon, I fear, destroy me.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Here were three of that company came safe to Land; but such impious Wretches, as did not deserve to escape, and such as no vertuous person can be concern'd for, sure; I was stiff with fear and horrour when I heard 'em talk.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Three, say you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: By this sad description it must be Don John, and his two wicked Associates; I am asham'd to confess the tenderness I have for him. Why should I love that Wretch? Oh my too violent passion hurries me I know not whether! into what fearful dangerous Labyrinths of misery will it conduct me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Were they Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: By their out-sides they seem'd so, but their in-sides declar'd them Devils.

lg.l: Heaven! it must be the Villain and his barbarous
Companions. They are reserv'd for my revenge:
Assist me, Heaven, in that just cause.
Oh, Villain, Villain! inhumane Villain!
Each minute is, me-thinks, a tedious Age,
Till I have dipt my hands in thy hearts bloud.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: You seem o'r-joy'd at the news of their safe arrival: Can any have a kindness for such dissolute abandon'd Atheists?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No; 'tis revenge that I persue against the basest of all Villains.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Have a care; Revenge is Heavens, and must not be usurp'd by Mortals.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Mine is revenge for Rapes and cruel murders, and those Heaven leaves to Earth to punish.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: They are horrid crimes, but Magistrates must punish them.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What do I hear? were he the basest of all men, my love is so head-strong and so wild within me, I must endeavour to preserve him, or destroy my self: to what deplorable condition am I fall'n? what Chains are these that hold me? Oh that I could break them! and yet I wou'd not if I cou'd; Oh my heart!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p:
They are gon to one Don Francisco's house, that Road
will bring you to it; 'tis on the other side of this Rock, in a pleasant Valley. I have not stirr'd these fourty years from these small bounds, or I wou'd give him notice what Devils he harbours in his house. You will do well to do it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: (within) Help, help, murder! I am drown'd, I am dead; Help, help!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Hah! what voice is that? I must assist him‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Father, farewell. Come, Madam, will you go to this house? Now, Monster, for my revenge.

lg.l: I will; but for different ends we go;
'Tis Love conducts me, but Revenge brings you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh help, help! I sink, I sink!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Poor man, sure he is almost drown'd.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, not yet; I have onely drunk something too much of a scurvy unpleasant Liquor.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Reach me your hand‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, and my heart too; Oh! Oh!

Sir, a thousand thanks to you: I vow to Gad, y'are a very civil person, and, as I am an honest man, have done me the greatest kindness in the world, next to the piece of the Mast which I floated upon, which I must ever love and honour; I am sorry it swam away, I wou'd have preserv'd it, and hung it up in the Seat of our antient Family.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Thank Heaven for your deliverance, and leave such vain thoughts.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I do with all my heart; but I am not setled enough to say my prayers yet: pray, Father, do you for me; 'tis nothing with you, you are us'd to it, it is your Trade.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Away, vain man; you speak as if you had drunk too deeply of another Liquor than Sea-water.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, I have not, but I wou'd fain: Where may a man light of a good Glass of Wine? I would gladly have an Antidote to my Poison. Methinks, Pah! these Fishes have but a scurvy time; I am sure they have very ill drinking.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Farewell, and learn more devotion and thankfulness to Heav'n‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Ha! 'tis uncivilly done to leave a man in a strange Country.
But these Hermits have no breeding. Poor Jacomo, Dear Jacomo, how I love thy person, how glad am I to see thee safe? for I swear, I think thou art as honest a fellow as e'r I met with. Well, farewell, thou wicked Element; if ever I trust thee again‚Äî Well, Haddocks, I desie you, you shall have none of me, no, not a Collop; no, no, I will be eaten by Worms, as all my Ancestors have been. If Heaven will but preserve me from the Monsters of the Land, my Master and his two Companions (who, I hope, are drown'd) I'll preserve my self from those of the Sea. Let me see, here is a path‚Äî this must lead to some house. I'll go, for I am plaguy sick with this Salt-water. Pah‚Äî

div.stage: Enter Clara and Flavia, with her two Maids.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, Flavia, this will be our last happy night, to morrow is our Execution day; we must marry.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Ay, Clara, we are condemn'd without reprieve. 'Tis better to live as we have done, kept from all men, than for each to be confin'd to one, whom yet we never saw, and a thousand to one shall never like.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Out on't, a Spanish Wife has a worse life than a coop'd Chicken.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: A singing Bird in a Cage is a Princely creature, compar'd to that poor Animal, call'd a Wife, here.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Birds are made tame by being cag'd, but Women grow wild by confinement, and that, I fear, my Husband will find to his cost.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: None live pleasantly here, but those who should be miserable, Strumpets: They can choose their Mates, but we must be like Slaves condemn'd to the Gallies; we have not liberty to sell our Selves, or venture one throw for our freedom.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O that we were in England! there, they say, a Lady may choose a Footman, and run away with him, if she likes him, and no dishonour to the Family.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: That's because the Families are so very Honourable, that nothing can touch them: there Wives run and ramble whither and with whom they please, and defie all censure.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ay, and a jealous Husband is a more monstrous Creature there, than a Wittall here, and wou'd be more pointed at: They say, if a man be jealous there, the women will all joyn and pull him to pieces.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Oh happy Countrey! we ne'r touch money, there the Wives can spend their Husbands Estates for 'em. Oh bless'd Countrey!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ay, there, they say, the Husbands are the prettiest civil easie good natur'd indifferent persons in the whole world; they ne'r mind what their Wives do, not they.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Nay, they say, they love those men best that are kindest to their Wives. Good men! poor hearts. And here, if an honest Gentleman offers a Wife a civility by the By, our bloudy butcherly Husbands are cutting of throats presently‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh that we had those frank civil English-men, instead of our grave dull surly Spanish Blockheads, whose greatest honour lies, in preserving their Beards and Foreheads inviolable.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: In England, if a Husband and Wife like not one another, they draw two several ways, and make no bones on't, while the Husband treats his Mistris openly in his Glass-Coach; the Wife, for decency's sake, puts on her Vizar, and whips away in a Hackney with a Gallant, and no harm done.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Though, of late, 'tis as unfashionable for a Husband to love his Wife there, as 'tis here, yet 'tis fashionable for her to love some body else, and that's something.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Nay, they say, Gentlemen will keep company with a Cuckold there, as soon as another man, and ne'r wonder at him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh happy Countrey! there a Woman may chuse for her self, and none will into the Trap of Matrimony, unless she likes the Bait; but here we are tumbl'd headlong and blindfold into it.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: We are us'd as they use Hawks, never unhooded, or whistled off, till they are just upon the Quarry.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And 'tis for others, not our selves, we fly too.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: No more, this does but put us in mind of our misery.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: It does so: but prethee let's be merry one night, to morrow is our last. Farewell all happiness.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p:
O that this happy day would last our lives-time. But
prethee, my Dear, let's have thy Song, and divert our selves as well as we can in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: 'Tis a little too wanton.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Prethee let's be a little wanton this evening, to morrow we must take our leaves on't.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Come on then; our Maids shall joyn in the Chorus: Here they are.

lg.l: WOman who is by Nature wild,
Dull bearded men incloses;
Of Nature's freedom we're beguil'd
By Laws which man imposes:
Who still himself continues sree,
Yet we poor Slaves must fetter'd be.
A shame on the Curse
Of, For better sor worse;
'Tis a vile imposition on Nature:
For Women should change,
And have freedom to range,
Like to every other wild Creature.
So gay a thing was ne'r design'd.
To be restrain'd from roving;
Heav'n meant so changeable a mind
Should have its change in loving.
By cunning we could make men smart,
But they by strength o'rcome our Art.
A shame on the Curse
Of, For, &c.
How happy is the Village Maid,
Whom onely Love can fetter;
By foolish Honour ne'r betray'd,
She serves a Pow'r much greater:
That lawful Prince the wisest rules,
Th‚ñ™ Usurper Honour rules but Fools.
A shame on the Curse
Of, For, &c.
Let us resume our antient right,
Make man at distance wonder;
Though he victorious be in sight,
In love we'll keep him under.
War and Ambition hence be hurl'd,
Let Love and Beauty rule the World.
A shame on the Curse
Of, For better, &c.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Oh, dear Clara, that this were true! But now let's home, our Father will miss us.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No, he's walk'd abroad with the three Shipwrack'd Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: They're proper handsome Gentlemen; but the chief, whom they call Don John, exceeds the rest.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I never saw a finer person; pray Heaven either of our Husbands prove as good.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Do not name 'em. Let the Maids go home, and if my Father be there, let him know we are here.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: In the mean time, if he be thereabouts, do you go down that Walk, and I'll go this way, and perhaps one of us shall light on him.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Agreed.

text.stage: Enter Don John, Don Lopez, Don Antonio.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Where have you left the Old man, Don Francisco?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: He's very busie at home, seeing all things prepar'd for his Daughters Weddings to moriow.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p:
His Daughters are gone this way: if you have any
friendship for me, go and watch the Old man; and if he offers to come towards us, divert him, that I may have freedom to attack his Daughters.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: You may be sure of us, that have serv'd you with our lives; besides, the justice of this cause will make us serve you. Adieu.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Now for my Virgins. Assist me, Love. Fools, you shall have no Maiden-heads to morrow-night. Husbands have Maiden-heads! no, no‚Äî poor sneaking Fools.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I have lost my way, I think I shall never find this house: But I shall never think my self out of my way, unless I meet my impious Master; Heaven grant he be drown'd.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: How now, Rascal, are you alive?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! he's here. Why was this leud Creature sav'd? I am in a worse condition than ever; now I have scap'd drowning, he brings hanging fresh into my memory.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: What mute, Sirra?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Sir, I am no more your Servant, you parted with me, I thank you, Sir, I am beholding to you: Farewell, good Sir, I am my own man now‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: No: though you are a Rogue, you are a necessary Rogue, and I'll not part with you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I must be gone, I dare not venture further with you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Sirra, do you know me, and dare you say this to me? have at your Guts, I will rip you from the Navel to the Chin.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O good Sir, hold, hold. He has got me in his clutches, I shall never get loose‚Äî Oh! Oh!‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come, Dog, follow me close, stinking Rascal.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I am too well pickl'd in the Salt-water to stink, I thank you, I shall keep a great while. But you were a very generous man, to leave a Gentleman, your Friend, in danger, as you did me. I have reason to follow you: but if I serve you not in your kind, then am I a sows'd Sturgeon.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Follow me, Sirra; I see a Lady.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Are you so fierce already?

text.stage: Enter Clara, singing, A shame on the Curse, &c.

lg.l: Ha! this is the Stranger;
What makes him here?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: A delicate Creature. Ha! this is the Lady. How happy am I to meet you here‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I was undone enough before, with seeing your Picture in the Gallery; but I see you have more Excellencies than Beauty, your Voice needed not have conspir'd with that to ruine me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Have you seen my Picture?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: And lov'd it above all things I ever saw, but the Original. I am lost beyond redemption, unless you can pity me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: He has been lost a hundred times, but he always sinds himself again‚Äî and me too; a pox on him.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: When Love had taken too fast hold on me, ever to let me go, I too late found you were to morrow to be marri'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Yes, I am condemn'd to one I never saw, and you are come to railly me and my misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, say not so, my Master is always in earnest.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: So much I am in earnest now, that if you have no way to break this marriage off, and pity me, I soon shall repent I ever came to Land; I shall suffer a worse wrack upon the Shoar, here I shall linger out my life in the worst of pains, despairing Love; there, I should have perish'd quickly‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ah poor man! he's in a desperate condition, I pity him with all my heart‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Peace, Rascal. Madam, this is the onely opportunity I am like to have; Give me leave to improve it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sure, Sir, you cannot be in earnest.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: If all the Oaths under the Sun can convince you, Madam, I swear‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O Sir, Sir, have a care of swearing, for fear you should, once in your life, be forsworn‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Peace, Dog, or I shall slit your Wind-pipe.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Nay, I know if he be forsworn, 'tis the first time, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But, Sir, if you be in earnest, and I had an inclination, Tis impossible to bring it about, my Father has dispos'd of me.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Dispose of your self, I'll do well enough with him, and my Fortune and Quality are too great for him, for whom you are intended, to dispute with me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: If this be true, wou'd you win a Woman at first sight?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Madam, this is like to be the first and last; to morrow is the fatal day that will undo me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Courage, Don, matters go well.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nay, I had rather have a Peasant of my own choosing, than an Emperor of another's. He is a handsome Gentleman, and seems to be of quality: Oh that he could rid me of my intended slavery.
Sir, talk not of impossible things; for could I wish this, my Father's Honour will not suffer him to dispense wtih his promise.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I'll carry you beyond his power, and your intended Husband's too.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: It cannot be; but I must leave you, I dare not be seen with you‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Remember the short time you have to think on this: will you let me perish without relief? if you will have pity on a wretched man, I have a Priest in my company, I'll marry you, and we'll find means to fly early in the morning, before the house are stirring.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I confess I am to be condemn'd to a Slavery, that nothing can be worse; yet this were a rash attempt.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: If you will not consent to my just desires, I am resolv'd to kill my self, and fall a Sacrifice to your disdain. Speak, speak my doom‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Hold, hold‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, hold, hold: poor foolish Woman, she shou'd not need to bid him hold.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I'll find a means this night to speak with you alone; but I fear this is but for your diversion.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis for diversion indeed; the common diversion of all the world.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: By all that's great and good, my intentions are honourable.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Farewell, Sir, I dare not stay longer.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Will you keep your word, Madam?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: You'll keep yours, no doubt‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I will, any thing rather than marry one I cannot love, as I can no man of another's choosing.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Remember, Madam, I perish if you do not; I have onely one thing to say, Keep this Secret from your Sister, till we have effected it; I'll give you sufficient reason for what I say.
Victoria, Victoria; I have her fast, she's my own.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: You are a hopeful man, you may come to good in time.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Here is the other Sister; have at her.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why, Sir, Sir; have you no conscience? Will not one at once serve your turn?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Stand by, Fool. Let me see, you are the Lady.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: What say you, Sir?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: You have lately taken up a stray heart of mine, I hope you do not intend to detain it, without giving me your own in exchange.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: I a heart of yours? since when, good Sir? you were but this day shipwrack'd on this Coast, and never saw my face before‚ñ™

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I saw your Picture, and I saw your motion, both so charming, I could not resist them; but now I have a nearer view, I see plainly I am lost.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: A goodly handsome man! but what can this mean?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Such killing Beauties I ne'r saw before; my heart is irrevocably gone.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Whether is it gone, Sir? I assure you I have no such thing about me, that I know of.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, if you wou'd give me leave to search you, I should find it in some little corner about you, that shall be nameless.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p:
It cannot be about me, I have none but my own „Äà‚óä„Äâ
that I must part with to morrow to I know not whom.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: If the most violent love that man e'r knew can e'r deserve that treasure, it is mine; if you give that away, you lose the truest Lover that e'r languish'd yet.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What can be the end of this? Sure Bloud‚ñ™ must follow this dishonour of the Family‚ñ™ and I unfortunate, shall have my throat cut for company.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Do you know where you are?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, in Spain, where opportunities are very „Äà‚óä„Äâ, and those that are wise make use of 'em as soon as they have 'em.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: You have a mind‚ñ™ to divert your self; but I must leave you, I am dispos'd to be more serious.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Madam, I swear by all‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Hold, hold; will you be forsworn again?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Peace, Villain, I shall cut that tongue out.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Farwell, I cannot stay.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I'll not leave her; I'll thaw her, if she were Ice, before I have done with her.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: There is no end of this lewdness. Well, I must be kill'd or hang'd once for all, and there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I am faint with what I suffer'd at Sea, and with my wandring since; let us repose a little, we shall not find this house to night.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ne'r shall rest till I have found Don Francisco's house; but I'll sit down a while.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I hope he will not find it, till I have found means to give Don John warning of his cruel intentions: I would save his life, who, I fear, would not do that for me. But in the miserable case that I am in, if he denies his love, death would be the welcom'st thing on earth to me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Oh my Octavio‚ñ™ how does the loss of thee perplex me with despair! the honour of Mankind is gone with thee. Why do I whine? grief shall no longer usurp the place of my revenge. How could I gnaw the Monster's heart, Villain! I'll be with you.
When I have reveng'd my dear Octavio's loss, I then shall diy contented.

text.stage: Enter Don Lopez and Don Antonio.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Th'old man's safe; I long to know Don John's success.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: He's engag'd upon a noble cause: if he succeeds, 'twill be a victory worth the owning.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Hah! whom have we here? a young man well habited, with a Lady too; they seem to be strangers.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: A mischief comes into my head, that's worth the doing.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: What's that, dear Antonio?

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: We are in a strange Countrey, and may want money: I would rob that young Fellow. We have not robb'd a good while; me-thinks 'tis a new wickedness to me.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Thou art in the right. I hate to commit the same dull sin over and over again, as if I were marri'd to it: variety makes all things pleasant.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: But there's one thing we'll ne'r omit. When we have robb'd the Man, we'll ravish the Woman.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Agreed; let's to't, man. Come on, young Gentleman, we must see what riches you have about you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O Villains! Thieves! Thieves! these are the inhumane Companions of that bloudy Monster.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Have pity on poor miserable Strangers.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Peace; we'll use you kindly, very kindly.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Do you carry that young Gentleman, bind him to a Tree, and bring the money, while I wait upon the Lady.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Will you play me no foul play in the mean time then? For we must cast Lots about the business you wot of.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: No, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Honour, you Villain?

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Come, young Gentleman, I'll tame you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Help! help‚Äî

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Have you no humanity in you? Take our money, but leave us liberty; be not so barb'rously cruel.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p:
Come, I have made haste with him; now let us draw
‚óè‚Ä¶uts who enjoys the Lady first.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: O heav'n assist me! what do I hear? help! help!

text.stage: Enter four or five Countrey Fellows, coming from work.

sp.speaker: 1. Count.
sp.p: Fel. What, two men a robbing of a Lady! Be gone, and let her alone, or we have sower Cudgels shall wasler your bones, I tell you that.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: How now, Rogues?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Thanks to Heav'n. I fly! I fly! where shall I hide my self?‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I shall conquer'em both. Now, Sirra, what think you?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why I think you manage your business as discreetly, and take as much pains to have your throat cut, as any man in Spain.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Your fear o'r-rules your sense, mine is a life Monarchs might envy.‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: 'Tis like to be a very short one at this rate.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Away, Fool, 'tis dark, I must be gone; I shall scarce find the way home‚Äî

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Heav'n guard me from these wicked Wretches. Help! help! they are here.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: How now, Madam? what‚ñ™ afraid of a Man!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Don John, no, not of you; you are the man i'th' world I wou'd have met.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Leonora, you are the woman i'th'world I would have avoided. 'Sdeath! she will spoil my new designs; but I have a trick for her. What miracle brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Love, that works the greatest miracles, made me follow you; and the same Storm drove me on this shoar, on which you were thrown, and thus far I've wander'd till I have found you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p:
This is the most unreasonable unsatiable loving Lady‚ñ™ that ever was abus'd by man; she has a kind of Spaniel love,
the worse you use her, the more loving she is. Pox on her, I must be rid of her.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I am very faint and weary, yet I was resolv‚ñ™ d not to rest till I had found you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Your unweari'd love has o'rcome and convinc'd me, there is not such a Woman breathing.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: This is a Sovereign Medicine for all my sorrows, I now, methinks, am happier than ever: but I am faint and ill.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Here, Madam, I have an excellent Cordial, 'twill refresh you; and I'll conduct you where you shall never be unhappy more.

lg.l: From that dear hand 'tis welcome‚Äî
To your health.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: And to your own destruction; you have drunk your last.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What means my Love?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Y'have drunk the subtlest poison that Art e'r yet invented.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O murder! murder! what have you done?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Peace, Villain, leave your unseasonable pity‚Äî You cannot live two minutes.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: O ungrateful Tyrant! thou hast murder'd the onely Creature living that cou'd love thee. Heaven will revenge it, though to me 'tis kindness. Here all my sorrows shall for ever cease.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Why would you persecute me with your love?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I could not help it. I came to preserve you, and am destroy'd for't.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh horrid fact!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: To preserve me! I wear my safety by my side.

lg.l: Oh I faint! Guard your self. There's a young
Gentleman pursues your life. Have a Care‚Äî
I came to tell you this, and thus I am rewarded.
Heav'n pardon you. Farewell. I can no more.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: This object sure will strike your heart! Tygers would melt at this. Oh the Earth will open and swallow you up, and me for company. There's no end of your murders‚Äî

lg.l: This is the first time I ever knew compassion.
Poor Fool, I pity her, but 'tis too late‚Äî
Farewell all sensless thoughts of a remorse,
I would remove what e'r wou'd stop my course.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: Enter Don John, Don Lopez, Don Antonio, Jacomo.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: THis nights success exceeded all my hopes. I had admittance to their several Chambers, and I have been contracted to both the Sisters, and this day resolve to marry 'em, and at several times enjoy them; and, in my opinion, I shall have a brace of as pretty Wives, as any man in Spain.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Brave Don John, you are Master of your Art, not a Woman in Spain can stand before you.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: We can but envy you, and at a distance imitate; But both their Maids shall to pot, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: How far will the Devil hurry you?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: 'Tis not the Devil, 'tis the Flesh, Fool.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Here will be fine cutting of throats. Poor Jacomo, must thou be cut off in the flower of thy Age?

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your Servant; I hope you rested well this night.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: We thank you, Sir; never better.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: We never shall requite this obligation.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I warrant you my Master will; he's a very grateful civil person indeed.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: The favour is too great to be suddenly requited; but I shall study to deserve it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Good man, you will deserve it.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you are come, you are early.

sp.speaker: 1. Brideg.
sp.p: This joyful occasion made us think it late.

sp.speaker: 2. Brideg.
sp.p: The expectation of so great a blessing as we this day hope to enjoy, would let us have but little rest last night.

sp.speaker: 1. Brideg.
sp.p: And the fruition will afford us less to night.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Poor Fools! you shall be bob'd. How it tickles my Spleen to think on't.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: These are to be my Sons in Law.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: And my Cuckolds before-hand.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Pray know 'em, Gentlemen; they are men of Honour.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I shall be glad to serve them;
But first I'll serve their Ladies.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, I'll now conduct you to my Daughters; and beg your pardon for a moment, I'll wait on you again.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: These Fools will spoil your design.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: No, poor Sots; I have perswaded the Ladies to feign sickness, and put off their marriage till to morrow morning, to gain time; in the mean while I have 'em safe, Boys.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: But will not the Sisters betray you to one another?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: No, I have wheedled each into a jealousie of the other, and each believes, that if the other knows it, she, in honour, will reveal it to the Father.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Sir, if you be so very weary of your life, why don't you make use of a convenient Beam? 'tis the easier way; so you may die without the filthy pother you keep about it.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Away, Coward; 'tis a sign I am not weary of my life, that I make so much use on't.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh Jacomo! thou art lost; 'tis pity a Fellow of thy neat spruce parts should be destroy'd.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, will you not refresh your selves with some cool Wines this morning?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: We thank you, Sir, we have already.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, here's a young Gentleman, a Stranger, desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: D. „Äà‚óä„Äâ.
sp.p: Admit him.
Your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, when I ve told you what I come for, I doubt not but I shall deserve your thanks. I come to do you service.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: You have'em, Sir, already‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You have lodg'd within your house some shipwrack'd men, who are greater Villains than the Earth e'r bore; I come to give you warning of 'em, and to beg your power to revenge such horrid actions, as heart could never yet conceive, or tongue could utter. Ha! they are these‚Äî Revenge, revenge cruel, unnatural Rapes and Murders. They are Devils in the shapes of men.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: What say you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Now the snare is faln upon me; me-thinks I feel cold Steel already in my body. Too well I know that face.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I know that face. Now, Impudence, assist me. What mad young man is that?

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: These, by their habits and their meens, are Gentlemen, and seem to be men of Honour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: By these two, last night, I was robb'd, and bound to a Tree, and there have been all night, and but this morning was reliev'd by Peasants‚Äî I had a Lady with me, whom they said they would ravish, and this morning I saw her dead; they must have murder'd her.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Heav'n! what do I hear?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! I am noos'd already, I feel the knot, methinks, under my left ear.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: The youth raves; we never saw his face, we never stirr'd from the bounds of this house since we came hither.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, let me kill the Villain; shall he thus affront men of our quality and honour?

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Hold, consider I am a Magistrate.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: The Youth was robb'd, and with the fright has lost his wits. Poor Fool! let him be bound in's bed.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Do not persist in this, but have a care: These injuries to men of Honour shall not go unpunished.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Whither shall injur'd Innocence fly for succour, if you so soon can be corrupted? Monster, I'll revenge my self; have at thy heart.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: What means the Youth? put up your Sword.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: We told you, Sir, he was mad.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh impudent Villains! I ask your pardon, Sir: My griefs and injuries transport me so, I scarce can utter them. That Villain is Don John, who basely murder'd the Governour of Sevil in his house, and then dishonour'd his fair Sister.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Death and Hell! this injury is beyond all sufferance.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, think in whose house you are.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O Lord! what will this come to? Ah Jacomo! thy line of life is short.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is the Villain, who kill'd the Lover of Antonio's Sister, deflow'rd her, and murder'd her Brother in his own house.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I'll have no longer patience.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Such a Villain should have his throat cut, though in a Church.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: No man of honour will protect those, who offer such injuries.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Have at you, Villain.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Nay then; Within there: Ho! I will protect him, or perish with him.

sp.speaker: 1. Brideg.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: This rashness will spoil my design upon the Daughters; if I had perfected that, I would have own'd all this for half a Duccatoon‚Äî

I ask your pardon for my ill manners; I was provok'd too far: indeed the accusations are so extravagant and odd, I rather
should have laugh'd at 'em. Let the young Fool have a vein open'd, he's stark staring mad.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: A foolish Impostor. We ne'r saw Sevil till last night.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh Impudence!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, not we; we never were there till yesterday. Pray, Sir, lay that young Fellow by the heels, for lying on us, men of Honour.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: What is the matter, Friend, you tremble so?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, the Dog's fear will betray us.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I tremble, Sir? no, no, Sir: I tremble‚Äî Though it would make any one tremble to hear one lie, as that young Gentleman does. Have you no conscience in you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Heav'n can witness for me, I speak not false. Octavio, my dear Octavio, being dearest to me of all the world, I would in Sevil have reveng'd his murder; but the Villain there escap'd me: I follow'd him to Sea, and in the same Storm in which their Ship perish'd, I was thrown on shoar. Oh my Octavio! if this foul unnatural murther be not reveng'd, there is no Justice left among mankind. His Ghost, and all the rest whom he has barbarously murder'd, will interrupt your quiet; they'll haunt you in your sleep. Revenge, revenge!

sp.speaker: 2. Bride.
sp.p: This is wonderful.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: There must be something in this; his passion cannot be counterfeited, nor your man's fear.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: My fear? I scorn your words; I fear nothing under the Sun. I fear? Ha, ha, ha‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Will you believe this one false Villain against three, who are Gentlemen, and men of honour?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Nay, against four, who are Gentlemen, and men of honour?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O Villain, that I had my Sword imbru'd in thy hearts bloud. Oh my dear Octavio! Do Justice, Sir, or Heav'n will punish you.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, he is too earnest, in his grief and anger, to be what you wou'd have him, an Impostor. My house has
been your Sanctuary, and I am oblig'd in honour not to act as a Magistrate, but your Host, no violence shall here be offer'd to you; but you must instantly leave this house, and if you would have safety, find it somewhere else. Be gone.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: This is very well.

lg.l: Oh! will you let 'em go unpunish'd?
Whither shall I flie for vengeance?

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Pray leave this place immediately.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ah, good Sir, let's be gone‚Äî Sir, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, consider what you do; do not banish Don John from hence.

sp.speaker: 1. Brideg.
sp.p: Ha! what means she?

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: What say you?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, he is my Husband, we were last night contracted.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Oh Heav'n! what do I hear?

sp.speaker: 1. Brideg.
sp.p: I am dishonour'd, abus'd. Villain, thou diest.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Villain, you lie; I will cut your throat first.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Hey, where are my people here.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, hold; if you banish Don John, I am lost for ever.

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Oh Devil! what do I hear?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: He is my Husband, Sir, we were last night contracted.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Your Husband! Heav'n! what's this?

sp.speaker: 2. Brideg.
sp.p: Hell and Damnation!

sp.speaker: D. Fran.
sp.p: Oh! I have lost my senses.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh Monster! now am I to be believ'd?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh spare my life! I am innocent as I hope to live and breath.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Dog, you shall fight for your life, if you have it.

sp.speaker: D. Franc.
sp.p: First, I'll revenge my self on these.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Hold, hold, they are both my Wives, and I will have them.
sp.stage: [Runs at his Daughters, they run out.

sp.speaker: D. Franc.
sp.p: Oh Devil! fall on‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fall on, I will assist you.
sp.stage: [They fight, Maria and Don Francisco are kill'd, the two Bridegrooms are hurt, Jacomo runs away.

lg.l: Now we've done their business.
Ah, cowardly Rogue! are not you a Son of a Whore?
Ay, Sir, what you please: A man had better be a living
Son of a Whore, than a dead Hero, by your favour.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I could find in my heart to kill the Rascal; his fear, some time or other, will undo us.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Hold, Sir; I went, Sir, to provide for your escape. Let's take Horses out of the Stable, and flie; abundance of Company are coming, expecting the Wedding, and we are irreparably lost if we take not this time. I think my fear will now preserve you.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: I think he counsels well. Let's flie to a new place of pleasure.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: But I shall leave my business undone with the two Women.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: 'Tis now scarce feizible. Let's sly; you'll light on others as handsom, where we come next.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Well, dispose of me as you please; and yet it troubles me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Haste, haste, or we shall be apprehended.

lg.l: O that I ever liv'd to see this day!
This fatall day! 'Twas our vile disobedience
Caus'd our poor Father's death, which Heav'n
Will revenge on us. So lewd a Villain
As Don John was never heard of yet.
That we should be so credulous! Oh dreadful
Accident! Dear Father, what Expiation can
We make? our crime's too foul for
Tears to wash away, and all our lives will
Be too short, to spend in penitence for this
Our levity and disobedience. He was the
Best of Fathers, and of Men.
What will become of us, poor miserable Maids,
Lost in our Fortunes and our Reputations?
Our intended Husbands, if they recover of their
Wounds, will murder us; and 'tis but Justice:
Our lives too now cannot be worth the keeping.
„Äà‚óä„Äâ Devils in the shapes of men are fled.
Let us not waste our time in fruitless grief;
Let us employ some to pursue the murderers.
And for our selves, let's to the next Monastery,
And there spend all our weary life in penitence.
Let's fly to our last Sanctuary in this world,
And try, by a Religious life, to expiate this Crime:
There is no safety, or no hope but there.
Let's go, and bid a long farewell to all the
World; a thing too vain, and little worth our care.
Agreed; farewell to all the vanity on Earth,
Where wretched Mortals, toss'd 'twixt hope and fear,
Must of all fix'd and solid joy despair.

div.head: The Scene is a delightful Grove.
div.stage: Enter two Shepherds and two Nimphs.

lg.l: Come Nimphs and Shepherds, haste away
To t‚óè‚Ä¶appy Sports within these shady Groves,
In pleasant lives time slides away apace,
But with the wretched seems to creep too slow.
Our happy leisure we employ in joys,
As innocent as they are pleasant. We,
Strangers to strife, and to tumultuous noise,
To baneful envy, and to wretched cares,
In rural pleasures spend our happy days,
And our soft nights in calm and quiet sleeps.
No rude Ambition interrupts our rest,
Nor base and guilty thoughts how to be great.
In humble Cottages we have such contents,
As uncorrupted Nature does afford,
Which the great, that surfeit under gilded Roofs,
And wanton in Down Beds, can never know.
Nature is here not yet debauch'd by Art,
'Tis as it was in Saturn's happy days:
Minds are not here by Luxury invaded;
A homely Plenty, with sharp Appetite,
Does lightsome health, and vigorous strength impart.
A chast-cold Spring does here refresh our thirst,
Which by no feavourish surfeit is increas'd;
Our food is such as Nature meant for Men,
Ere with the Vicious, Eating was an Art.
In noisie Cities riot is persu'd,
And lewd luxurious living softens men,
Effeminates Fools in Body and in Mind,
Weakens their Appetites, and decays their Nerves.
With filthy steams from their excess of Meat,
And clowdy vapours rais'd from dangerous Wine;
Their heads are never clear or free to think,
They waste their lives in a continual mist.
Some subtil and ill men chuse Temperance,
Not as a Vertue, but a Bawd to Vice,
And vigilantly wait to ruine those,
Whom Luxury and Ease have lull'd asleep.
Yes, in the clamorous Courts of tedious Law,
Where what is meant for a relief's a gievance;
Or in Kings Palaces, where Cunning strives,
Not to advance King's Interests, but its own.
There they in a continual hurry live,
And seldom can, for all their subtile Arts,
Lay their foundations sure; but some
Are undermin'd, others blown down by storms.
Their subtilty is but a common Road
Of flattering great men, and oppressing little,
Smiling on all they meet, and loving none.
In populous Cities, life is all a storm;
But we enjoy a sweet perpetual calm:
Here our own Flocks we keep, and here
I and my Phillis can embrace unenvi'd.

sp.speaker: 2. Shep.

lg.l: And I and Caelia without jealousie.
But hark, the Pipes begin; now for our sports.
NImphs and Shepherds come away,
In these Groves let's sport and play;
Where each day is a Holy-day,
Sacred to Ease and happy Love.
To Dancing, Musick, Poetry:
Your Flocks may now securely rove.
Whilst you express your jollity.

sp.stage: Enter Shepherds and Shepherdesses, singing in Chorus‚ñ™

lg.l: We come, we come, no joy like this.
Now let us sing, rejoyce, and kiss.
The Great can never know such bliss

sp.p: As this.
As this.
As this.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: As this.
The Great can never know such bliss

lg.l: All th' Inhabitants o'th'Wood,
Now celebrate the Spring,
That gives fresh vigour to the bloud
Of every living thing.
The Birds have been singing and billing before us,
And all the sweet Choristers joyn in the Chorus.
The Nightingales with jugging throats,
Warble out their pretty Notes,
So sweet, so sweet, so sweet:
And thus our Loves and Pleasures greet.
Then let our Pipes sound, let us dance, let us sing,
Till the murmuring Groves with loud Eccho's shall ring.
How happy are we,
From all jealousie free;
No dangers or cares can annoy us:
We toy and we kiss,
And Love's our chief bliss;
A pleasure that never can cloy us.
Our days we consume in unenvi'd delights,
And in love and soft rest our happy long nights.
Each Nimph does impart
Her love without Art,
To her Swain, who thinks that his chief Treasure.
No envy is fear'd,
No sighs are e'r heard,
But those which are caus'd by our pleasure.
When we feel the bless'd Raptures of innocent Love,
No joys exceed ours but the pleasures above.
In these delightful fragrant Groves,
Let's celebrate our happy Loves.
Let's pipe, and dance, and laugh, and sing;
Thus every happy living thing,
Revels in the cheerful Spring.

div.stage: Enter Don John, Don Lopez, Don Antonio, Jacomo.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: So, thus far we are fafe, we have almost kill'd our Horses with riding cross out of all Roads.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Nay, you have had as little mercy on them, as if they had been Men or Women: But yet we are not safe, let us fly farther.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: The house I lighted at was mine during my life, which I sold to that fellow; he, since he holds by that tenure, will carefully conceal us.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: ‚ñ™ Tis a Tenure I will not give him two moneths purchase for.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Besides, our Swords are us'd to conquest.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: At worst, there is a Church hard by; we'll put it to its proper use, take refuge in't.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Look here, here are Shepherds, and young pretty Wenches; shall we be idle, Don?

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: By no means; 'tis a long time, methinks, since we were vicious.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: We'll serve 'em as the Romans did the Sabines, we'll rob 'em of their Women; onely we'll return the Punks again, when we have us'd them.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: For Heav'ns sake hold.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Sirra, no more; do as we do, ravish, Rascal, or, by my Sword, I'll cut thee into so many pieces, it shall pose an Arithmetician to sum up the fractions of thy body.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I ravish! Oh, good Sir! my courage lies not that way; alas, I, I am almost famish'd, I have not eat to day.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Sirra, by Heaven do as I bid thee, or thou shalt never eat again. Shall I keep a Rascal for a Cypher?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! what will become of me? I must do it.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come on, Rogue, fall on.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Which are you for?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: 'Tis all one, I am not in Love but in Lust, and to such a one a Belly-full's a Belly-full, and there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: 1. Shepherdess.
sp.p: What means this violence?

sp.speaker: 2. Shepherdess.
sp.p: Oh! Heav'n protect us.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Well, I must have one too; if I be hang'd, I had as good be hang'd for something.
sp.stage: [Every one runs off with a Woman.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Rogues, come not on; we'll be in your guts.

sp.speaker: All Shepherdess.
sp.p: Help, help.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.p: What Devils are these?
sp.stage: [Three or four Shepherds return with Jacomo.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.p: Here's one Rogue. Have we caught you, Sir? we'll cool your courage.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Am I taken prisoner? I shall be kept as an honourable Hostage, at least‚Äî

sp.speaker: 2. Shep.
sp.p: Where are these Villains, these Ravishers?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Why you need not keep such a stir, Gentlemen, you will
have all your Women again, and no harm done. Let me go, I'll fetch 'em to you.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.p: No, you libidinous Swine; we'll revenge the Rapes on you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Good kind civil people pass this by: 'Tis true, my Master's a very Tarquin; but I ne'r attempted to ravish before.

sp.speaker: 2. Shep.
sp.p: I'll secure you from ever doing of it again. Where's your Knife?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Heav'n! what do you mean? Oh spare me! I am unprepar'd; let me be confest.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.p: We will not kill you, we'll but geld you: Are you so hot, Sir?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh bloudy Villains! have a care, 'tis not a season for that, the Sign's in Scorpio.

sp.speaker: 2. Shep.
sp.p: Down with him‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O help, help! murder, murder! Have a care what you do, I am the last of all my Race‚Äî Will you destroy a whole Stock, and take away my Representers of my Family?‚Äî

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.p: There shall be no more of the Breed of you‚Äî‚ñ™

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I am of an antient Family; will you cut off all hopes of a Son and Heir? Help! help! Master, Don John? Oh! Oh! Oh!

div.stage: Enter Don John, Don Lopez, Don Antonio.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: How now, Rogues? do you abuse my Man?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O Sir, this is the first good thing you ever did: if you had not come just in the Nick, I had lost my Manhood.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for the use you make on't.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: But come, let's now to Supper.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Come on, I am almost starv'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.p: Let's not complain, but Dog the Rogues, and when we have Hous'd 'em, we will to the next Magistrate, and beg his pow'r to apprehend 'em.

div.stage: The Scene changes to a Church, with the Statue of Don Pedro on Horseback in it.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Let's in, and see this Church.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Is this a time to see Churches? But let me see whose Statue's this? Oh Heav'n! this is Don Pedro's, whom you murder'd at Sevil.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Say you so? Read the Inscription.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Here lies Don Pedro, Governour of Sevil, barbarously murder'd by that impious Villain, Don John, gainst whom his innocent bloud cries still for vengeance.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Let it cry on. Art thou there i'faith?‚ñ™ Yes, I kill'd thee, and wou'd do't again upon the same occasion. Jacomo‚Äî invite him to Supper.

sp.speaker: Jac
sp.p: What, a Statue! invite a Statue to Supper? Ha, ha‚Äî can Marble eat?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I say, Rascal, tell him I would have him Sup with me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! who the Devil put this‚ñ™ whimsey into your head? Ha, ha, ha! invite a Statue to Supper?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I shall spoil your mirth, Sirra; I will have it done.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why, 'tis impossible; wou'd you have me such a Coxcomb, invite Marble to eat? Ha, ha, ha.
sp.stage: [He goes several times towards the Statue, and returns laughing.
sp.p: Good Mr. Statue, if it shall please your Worship, my Master desires you to make Collation with him presently‚Äî
sp.stage: [The Statue nods his head, Jacomo falls down and roars.
sp.p: Oh I am dead! Oh, Oh, Oh.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: The Statue nods its head; 'tis odd‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis wonderful.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: I am amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh I cannot stir! Help, help.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Well, Governour, come, take part of a Collation with me, 'tis by this time ready; make haste, 'tis I invite you.
Say you so? come on, let's set all things in order quickly.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh fly, fly.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: This is prodigious.
sp.stage: [Exeunt Don John, Don Lopez, Don Antonio, Jacomo.

div.head: The Scene is a Dining Room, a Table spread, Servants setting on Meat and Wine.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come, our meat is ready, let's sit. Pox on this foolish Statue, it puzles me to know the reason on't. Sirra, I'll give you leave to sit.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Let's eat, ne'r think on't.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, come, let's eat; I am too hungry now to think on the fright‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: This is excellent Meat. How the Rogue eats. You'll choak your self.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I warrant you, look to yourself.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Why, Jacomo, is the Devil in you?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, no; if he be, 'tis a hungry Devil.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Will you not drink?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I'll lay a good foundation first.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: The Rascal eats like a Canibal.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis no matter for that.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Some Wine, Sirra.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: There, Sir, take it; I am in haste.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, the Fool will be strangl'd.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: The Fool knows what he does.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Here's to Don Pedro's Ghost, he should have been welcome.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O name him not.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: The Rascal is afraid of you after death.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! some Wine, give me some Wine.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Take it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: So, now 'tis down.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Are you not satisfi'd yet?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Peace, peace; I have but just begun.
Who's there? come in, I am very busie.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Rise, and do your duty.

sp.speaker: Jac.

lg.l: But one morsel more, I come. [Knocks again.
What a pox, are you mad?

sp.p: Oh! the Devil, the Devil.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Hah! it is the Ghost, let's rise and receive him.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: I am amaz'd.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Not frighted are you?

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: I scorn the thoughts of fear.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come, Governour, you are welcome, sit there; if we had thought you would have come, we wou'd have staid for you. But come on, Sirra, give me some Wine.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! I am dead; what shall I do? I dare not come near you.

sp.speaker: D, Joh.
sp.p: Come, Rascal, or I'll cut your throat.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I come, I come. Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Why do you tremble, Rascal? hold it steadily‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! I cannot.
sp.stage: [Jacomo snatches meat from the Table, and runs aside.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Here, Governour, your health. Friends, put it about. Here's excellent meat; taste of this Ragoust. If you had had a body of flesh, I would have given you cher entire‚Äî but the Women care not for Marble. Come, I'll help you. Come, eat and let old quarrels be forgotten.

lg.l: I come not here to take repast with you;
Heaven has permitted me to animate
This Marble body and I come to warn
You of that vengeance is in store for you,
If you amend not your pernicious lives.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh Heav'n!

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: What, are you come to preach to us?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Keep your Harangues for Fools that will believe 'em.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p:
We are too much confirm'd. Pox o' this dry discourse,
give me some Wine. Come, here's to your Mistris; you had one when you were living: not forgetting your sweet Sister‚ñ™ Sirra, more Wine.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, Sir‚Äî Good Sir, do not provoke the Ghost; his Marble fists may fly about your ears, and knock your brains out.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Peace, Fool.

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.p: Tremble, you impious Wretches, and repent; Behold, the pow'rs of Hell wait for you‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! I will steal from hence. Oh the Devil!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Sirra, stir not; by Heav'n I'll use thee worse than Devils can do. Come near, Coward.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O I dare not stir; what will become of me?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come, Sirra, eat.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O, Sir, my appetite is satisfied.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Drink, Dog, the Ghost's health: Rogue, do't, or I'll run my Sword down your throat.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! Here, Mr. Statue, your health.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Now, Rascal, sing to entertain him.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Sing, quoth he! Oh! I have lost my voice; I cannot be merry in such company. Sing‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Who are these with ugly shapes?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Their manner of appearing is something strange.

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.p: They're Devils, that wait for such hard impious Men. They're Heavens Instruments of eternal vengeance.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Are they some of your Retinue? Devils, say you? I am sorry I have no Burnt Brandey to treat'em with, that's Drink fit for Devils‚Äî Hah! they vanish.

lg.l: Cannot the fear of Hell's eternal tortures,
Change the horrid course of your abandon'd lives?
Think on those Fires, those everlasting Fires,
That shall without consuming burn you ever.
Dreams, dreams, too slight to lose my pleasure for.
In spight of all you say I will go on,
Till I have surfeited on all delights.
Youth is a Fruit that can but once be gather'd,
And I'll enjoy it to the full.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Let's push it on; Nature chalks out the way that we should follow.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: 'Tis her fault, if we do what we should not. Let's on, here's a Brimmer to our Leader's health.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What hellish Fiends are these?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Let me tell you, 'tis something ill bred to rail at your Host, that treats you civilly. You have not yet forgot your quarrel to me.

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.p: 'Tis for your good; by me Heaven warns you of its wrath, and gives you a longer time for your repentance. I invite you this night to a repast of mine.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.p: At my Tomb.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: What time?

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.p: At dead of night.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: We'll come.

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.p: Fail not.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.p: Farewell, and think upon your lost condition.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Farewell, Governour; I'll see what Treat you'll give us.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: That will not I. Pox on him, I have had enough of his company, I shall not recover it this week. If I eat with such an Host, I'll be hang'd.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: If you do not, by Heaven you shall be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Whither will your lewdness carry me? I do not care for having a Ghost for my Landlord. Will not these Miracles do good upon you?

lg.l: There's nothing happens but by Natural Causes,
Which in unusual things Fools cannot find,
And then they stile 'em Miracles. But no Accident
Can alter me from what I am by Nature.
Were there‚Äî
Legions of Ghosts and Devils in my way,
One moment in my course of pleasure I'd not stay.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Enter Jacomo, with Back, Breast, and Head-piece.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: WEll, this damn'd Master of mine will not part with me; and we must fight five or six times a day, one day with another, that's certain: Therefore thou art wise, honest Jacomo, to arm thy self, I take it. Sa, sa, sa‚Äî Methinks I am very valiant on the sudden. Sa, sa, sa. Hah! there I have you. Paph‚Äî Have at you. Hah‚Äî there I have you through: that was a fine thrust in tierce. Hah‚Äî Death! what noise is that?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: How now, Sirra, what are you doing?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Nothing, but practising to run people through the bodies, that's all; for I know some body's throat must be cut before midnight.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: In Armour too! why, that cannot help you, you are such a cowardly Fool; fear will betray you faster within, than that can defend you without‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I fear no body breathing, I; nothing can terrifie me but the Devillish Ghost. Ha! who's that coming? Oh Heaven!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Is this your courage? you are preparing for flight before an Enemy appears.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, no, Sir, not I; I onely leapt back to put my self upon my guard‚Äî Fa, la, la‚Äî

div.stage: Enter Don Lopez and Don Antonio.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Whom have we here?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh where! where! who are they?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Oh my Friends! where have you been?

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: We went to view the stately Nunnery hard by, and have been chatting with the poor sanctifi'd Fools, till it's dark; we have been chaffering for Nuns-flesh.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: There I made such a discovery, if you do not assist me, I am ruin'd for ever. Don Bernardo's Sister, whom I fell in love with in Sevil, is this day plac'd there for probation; and if you cannot advise me to some way or other of getting her out, for some present occasion I have for her, I am a lost man, that's certain.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: The business is difficult, and we resolve to manage it in council.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Now will they bring me into some wicked occasion or other of shewing my prowess: a pox on 'em.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Have you so long followed my fortunes, to boggle at difficulty upon so honourable an occasion; besides, here is no difficulty.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: No? the Walls are so high, and the Nunnery so strongly fortifi'd, 'twill be impossible to do it by force; we must find some stratagem.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: The stratagem is soon found out‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: As how, Don John?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Why, I will set fire on the Nunnery; fire the Hive, and the Drones must out, or be burnt within: then may you, with ease, under pretence of succour, take whom you will.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: 'Tis a gallant design.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: I long to be about it. Well, Don, thou art the bravest Fellow breathing.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Gentlemen, pray what became of that brave Fellow, that fir'd the Temple at Ephesus? was he not hang'd, Gentlemen, hum‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: We are his Rivals, Fool; and who would not suffer for so brave an action?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: He's a Scoundrel and a Poultroon, that would not have his Death for his Fame.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: That he is, a damn'd Son of a Whore, and not fit to drink with.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
'Tis a rare thing to be a Martyr for the Devil; But what good will infamy do you, when you are dead? when Honour
is nothing but a vapour to you, while you are living. For my part I'd not be hang'd to be Alexander the Great.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: What a phlegmatick dull Rascal is that, who has no Ambition in him.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ambition! what, to be hang'd? besides, what's the intrinsick value of Honour when a man is under ground? Let '‚óè‚Ä¶m but call me honest Jacomo, as I am, while I live, and let 'em call me, when I am dead, Don John if they will.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Villain, dare you profane my name?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, think what you do; you cannot hurt me, my Arms are Pistol-proof.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I come to give you notice of an approaching danger: You must fly; an Officer with some Shepherds have found you were at our house, and are come to apprehend you, for some outrage you have committed; I came to give you notice, knowing our Family has a great respect for you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Yes, I know your Family has a great respect for me, for I have lain with every one in it, but thee and thy Master.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why look you now, I thought what 'twou'd come to: Fly, Sir, fly; the darkness of the night will help us. Come, I'll lead the way.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Stay, Sirra, you shall have one occasion more of showing your valour.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Did ever any Knight Errant fly, that was so well appointed?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: No; you shall stay, and get Honour, Jacomo.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Pox of Honour, I am content with the Stock I have already.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: You are easily satisfied. But now let's fire the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Come on.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: I long to be at it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
O Jacomo! thy life is not worth a Piece of Eight. 'Tis in vain to disswade 'em, Sir; I will never trouble you with another
request, if you'll be graciously pleas'd to leave me out of this adventure.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Well, you have your desire.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: A thousand thanks; and when I see you again, I will be humbly content with a Halter.

sp.speaker: D. Joh
sp.p: But, do you hear, Fool? stand Centinel here; and if any thing happens extraordinary, give us notice of it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O, good Sir! what do you mean? that's as bad as going with you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Let me find you here when I come again, or you are a dead man‚Äî
sp.stage: [Exeunt Don John, Don Lopez, Don Antonio.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I am sure I am a dead man, if you find me here: But would my Armour were off now, that I might run the lighter. Night assist me. Heaven! what noise is that? to be left alone in the dark, and fear Ghosts and Devils, is very horrible. But Oh‚ñ™ who are these?

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.p: We are thus far right; the Ravishers went this way.

sp.speaker: 2. Shep.
sp.p: For Heavens sake take 'em dead or alive; such desperate Villains ne'r were seen.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: So; if I be catch'd, I shall be hang'd; if not, I shall be kill'd. 'Tis very fine. These are the Shepherds. I'll hide my self.
sp.stage: [He stands up close against the Wall.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.p: If we catch the Rogues, we will broil 'em alive; no death can be painful enough for such Wretches.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O bloudy minded men‚Äî

sp.speaker: 2. Shep.
sp.p: O impious vile Wretches! that we had you in our clutches! Open your Dark Lantern, and let's search for 'em.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What will become of me? my Armour will not do now.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.p: Thus far we hunted them upon a good scent: but now we are at a fault.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Let me see; I have one trick left, I have a Disguise will fright the Devil.

sp.speaker: 2. Shep.
sp.p: They must be hereabouts.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I'll in amongst them, and certainly this will „Äà‚óä„Äâ „Äà‚óä„Äâ.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.p: Oh Heav'n! what horrid Object's this?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: The Devil.

sp.speaker: 2. Shep.
sp.p: Oh fly, fly! the Devil, the Devil! fly‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Farewell, good Gentlemen. This is the first time my face e'r did me good. But I'll not stay I take it; Yet whether shall I fly? Oh! what noise is that? I am in the dark, in a strange place too; what will follow? There lie. Oh! my Arms. Hah! Who's there? Let me go this way‚Äî Oh the Ghost! the Ghost! Gad forgive me, 'twas nothing but my fear‚Äî
sp.stage: [A noise within, Fire, Fire, the Nunnery's on fire.
sp.p: Oh vile Wretches! they have done the deed. There is no flying; now the place will be full of people, and wicked Lights, that will discover me, if I fly.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Fire, fire, fire; the Nunnery's on fire; help, help‚Äî
sp.stage: [Several people cross the Stage, crying Fire.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What shall I do? there's no way but one, I'll go with the Crowd. Fire! Fire‚Äî Murder! help! help! fire! fire‚Äî
sp.stage: [More people cross the Stage, he runs with them.
Enter Don John, Don Antonio, Don Lopez, four Nuns.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Fear not, Ladies, we'll protect you.

sp.speaker: 1. Nun.
sp.p: Our Sex and Habits will protect us.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Not enough, we will protect you better.

sp.speaker: 1. Nun.
sp.p: Pray leave us, we must not consort with men.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: What would you run into the fire to avoid Mankind? you are zealous Ladies indeed.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come, Ladies, walk with us; we'll put you in a place of safety.

sp.speaker: 1. Nun.
sp.p: We'll go no further, we are safe enough; be gone, and help to quench the fire.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: We have another fire to quench; come along with us.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Ay, come, you must go.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Come along, we know what's good for you; you must go with us.

sp.speaker: 1. Nun.
sp.p: Heaven! what violence is this? what impious men are these? Help! help!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Here are the bloudy Villains, the causes of our misery.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Inhumane Butchers! now we'll have your lives.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Hah! here are a brace of my Wives. If you have a mind to this Fool, take her betwixt you; for my part, I'll have my own. Come, Wives, along with me; we must consummate, my Spouses, we must consummate.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What Monsters are these?

sp.speaker: All Nuns.
sp.p: Help! help!

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! these foolish Women are their own Enemies.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Here are so many people, if they cry out more, they'll interrupt us in our brave design.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: I warrant you; when they cry out, let us out-noise 'em. Come, Women, you must go along with us.

sp.speaker: 1. Nun.
sp.p: Heaven! what shall we do? Help! help!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Help! help! Fire! fire! fire!

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Help! help!

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Help! help!
sp.stage: [They hale the Women by the hands, who still cry out, and they with them.

div.stage: Enter several people, crying out Fire, Jacomo in the rear.

lg.l: Fire! fire! fire! Help! help!
'Sdeath! here's my Master,

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Sirra, come along with me, I have use of you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I am caught.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Here, Sirra, take one of my Wives, and force her after me. Do you refuse, Villain?

div.stage: Enter Shepherds, with Officer and Guards.

sp.speaker: Nuns.
sp.p: Help! help! good people help! rescue us from these Villains.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.p: Who are you, committing violence on Women?

sp.speaker: 2. Shep.
sp.p: Heavens! they are the Villains we seek for.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Where is my Armour now? Oh my Armour.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Fall on.
sp.stage: [They fight, Women fly, Jacomo falls down as kill'd, two Shepherds and the Officer are kill'd.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Say you so, Rogues?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: So, the Field's our own.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: But a pox on't, we have bought a Victory too dear, we have lost the Women.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: We'll find 'em again. But poor Jacomo's kill'd.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: That's a lie.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: 'Faith, let's carry off our dead.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Agreed; we'll bury him in the Church, while the Ghost treats us, we'll treat the Worms with the body of a Rascal.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Not yet a while.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Come, let's take away the Fool.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, the Fool can take up himself. 'Sdeath! you resolve not to let me alone dead or alive‚Äî
Here are more Murders. Oh!

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Oh counterfeiting Rascal! are you alive?

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: The Clock strikes Twelve.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: 'Slife, our times come, we must to the Tomb: I would not break my word with the Ghost for a thousand Doubloons‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Nor I keep it for ten times the Money.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: But you shall keep your word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Sir, I am resolv'd to fast to night, 'tis a Vigil: Besides, I care not for eating in such base company.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Follow, follow, follow‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p:
D'hear that noise? the remaining Rogues have rais'd
the Mobile, and are coming upon us.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! let's flie‚Äî flie‚Äî what will become of me?

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Let's to the Church, and give the Rogues the Go-by.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Come on, since 'tis my time, and I have promis'd the Governour, I'll go‚Äî You had best stay, Sirra, and be taken.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No: now I must go to the Church whether I will or no. Away, away, flie!
sp.stage: Enter two Shepherds, with a great Rabble.
sp.p: Here they went; follow, follow‚Äî

div.head: The Scene the Church, the Statue of Don Pedro on Horseback; on each side of the Church, Don John's Ghost, Maria's, Don Francisco's, Leonora's, Flora's, Maria's Brothers, and others, with Torches in their hands.
div.stage: Enter Don John, Don Antonio, Don Lopez, Jacomo.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Good Sir, let's go no farther; look what horrid Attendants are here. This wicked Ghost has no good meaning in him.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: He resolves to treat us in State; I think he has robb'd all the Graves hereabouts of their Dead, to wait upon us.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: I see no Entertainment prepar'd.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: He has had the manners to light off his Horse, and entertain us.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: He would not sure be so ill bred, to make us wait on him on foot.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Pox on his breeding, I shall die with fear; I had as good have been taken and hang'd. What horror seizes me!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Well, Governour, you see we are as good as our words.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Where's your Collation?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Bid some of your Attendants give us some Wine.

lg.l: Have you not yet thought on your lost condition?
Here are the Ghosts of some whom you have murder'd,
That cry for vengeance on you‚Äî

sp.speaker: Fathers Ghost.
sp.p: Repent, repent of all your horrid crimes: Monsters, repent, or Hell will swallow you.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: That's my Old man's voice. D'hear, Old Gentleman, you talk idly.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I do repent, O spare me. I do repent of all my sins, but especially of following this wicked Wretch.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Away, Fool

sp.speaker: D. Fran. Ghost.
sp.p: My bloud cries out upon thee, barbarous Wretch.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: That's my Host Francisco, 'faith thou wert a good honest Blockhead, that's the truth on't‚Äî

sp.speaker: Flora's Ghost.
sp.p: Thou shalt not escape vengeance for all thy crimes.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: What Fool's that, I am not acquainted with her.

sp.speaker: Leon. Ghost.
sp.p: In time lay hold on mercy, and repent.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: That was Leonora, a good natur'd silly Wench, something too loving, that was all her fault.

lg.l: Villain, this is the last moment of thy life,
And thou in flames eternally shalt howl.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Thou li'st. This is the young hot-headed Fool we kill'd at Francisco's. Pox on him, he disappointed me in my design upon the Daughters. Would thou wert alive again, that I might kill thee once more.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: No more of this old foolish stuff; give us some Wine to begin with.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Ay, give us some Wine, Governour.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: What, do you think to treat us thus? I offer'd you a better entertainment. Prethee trouble us no more, but bid some of your Attendants give us some Wine; I'll drink to you and all the good Company.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.p: Give 'em the Liquor they have most delighted in.
sp.stage: [Two of the Ghosts go out, and bring four Glasses full of bloud, then give 'em to D. John, D. Ant. D. Lop.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: This is something.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: This is civil.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: I hope a good desert will follow.
sp.stage: [Ghost offers a Glass to Jacomo, who runs round D. John, D. Ant. D. Lop. roaring.

sp.speaker: Jac.
