sp.p: Are you stark distracted? will you drink of that liquor? Oh! Oh! what d'you mean? Good sweet Ghost forbear your civility; Oh I am not dry, I thank you‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Give it me. Here, take it, Sirra.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: By no means, Sir, I never drink between meals. Oh Sir‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Take it, Rascal.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh Heav'ns!

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Now, Governour, your Health; 'tis the reddest drink I ever saw.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Hah! pah! 'tis bloud.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: Pah! it is‚Äî

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh! I'll have none of it.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, do you mean to affront us?

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.p: 'Tis fit for such bloud-thirsty Wretches.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Do you upbraid me with my killing of you; I did it, and would do it again: I'd fight with all your Family one by one; and cut off root and branch to enjoy your Sister. But will you treat us yet no otherwise?

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.p: Yes, I will, ye impious Wretches.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: What's here? Musick to treat us with?

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: There is some pleasure in this.

lg.l: PRepare, prepare, new Guests draw near,
And on the brink of Hell appear.
Kindle fresh flames of Sulphur there.
Assemble all ye Fiends,
Wait for the dreadful ends
Of impious men; who far excel
All th' Inhabitants of Hell.
‚Äî Let 'em come, let 'em come,
To an eternal dreadful doom,
Let 'em come, let 'em come.
In mischiefs they have all the damn'd outdone;
Here they shall weep, and shall unpiti'd groan,
Here they shall howl, and make eternal moan.
By Bloud and Lust they have deserv'd so well,
That they shall feel the hottest flames of Hell.
In vain they shall here their past mischiess bewail,
In exquisite torments that never shall fail.
Eternal darkness they shall find,
And them eternall Chains shall bind
To infinite pain of sense and mind.
‚Äî Let 'em come, let 'em come,
To an eternal dreadful doom
Let 'em come, let 'em come.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.p: Will you not relent, and feel remorse?

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Cou'dst thou bestow another heart on me, I might; but with this heart I have, I cannot.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: These things are prodigious.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: I have a kind of grudging to relent, but something holds me back.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: If we could, 'tis now too late; I will not.

sp.speaker: D. Ant.
sp.p: We defie thee.

sp.speaker: Stat.

lg.l: Perish, ye impious Wretches, go and find
The punishments laid up in store for you.

sp.stage: [It Thunders, Don Lopez and Don Antonio are swallow'd up.
sp.p: Behold their dreadful Fates, and know, that thy last moment's come.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Think not to fright me, foolish Ghost; I ll break your Marble body in pieces, and pull down your Horse.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: If fear has left me my strength, I'll steal away.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.

lg.l: These things I see with wonder, but no fear.
Were all the Elements to be confounded,
And shuffl'd all into their former Chaos;
Were Seas of Sulphur flaming round about me,
And all Mankind roaring within those fires,
I could not fear or feel the least remorse.
To the last instant I would dare thy power.
Here I stand firm‚ñ™ and all thy threats contemn;
Thy Murderer stands here, now do thy worst.

sp.stage: [It Thunders and Lightens, Devils descend and sink with Don John, who is cover'd with a Clowd of fire as he sinks.

lg.l: Thus perish all,
Those men, who by their words and actions dare,
Against the will and power of Heaven declare.
THrough all the Perils of the Play I've run,
But know not how your fury I may shun;
I'm in new dangers now to be undone‚Äî
I had but one sierce Master there,
But I have many cruel Tyrants here.
Who do most bloudily my life persue;
Who takes my Livelihood, may take that too.
'Gainst little Players you great factions raise,
Make Solemn Leagues and Cov'nants against Plays.
We, who by no Allies assisted are,
Against the Great Confederates must make War.
You need not strive our Province to o'r-run,
By our own stratagems we are undone.
We've laid out all our Pains, nay Wealth for you,
And yet, hard-hearted men, all will not do.
'Tis not your Judgments sway for you can be
Pleas'd with damn'd Plays (as heart can wish to see)
'Ounds, we do what we can, what wou'd you more?
Why do you come, and rant, and damn, and roar?
'Sdeath, what a Devil would you have us do?
Each take a Prison, and there humbly sue,
Angling for single Money with a Shoo.
What, will you be Don Johns? have you no remorse?
Farewell then, bloudy men, and take your course.
Yet stay‚Äî
If you'll be civil, we will treat of Peace,
And th' Articles o'th' Treaty shall be these.
First, to the men of Wit we all submit;
The rest shall swagger too within the Pit,
And may roar out their little or no Wit.
But do not swear so loud to fright the City,
Who neither care for wicked men, nor witty;
They start at ills they do not like to do,
But shall in Shops be wickeder than you.

l.hi: Next, you'll no more be troubl'd with Machines.

lg.l: Item, you shall appear behind our Scenes,
And there make love with the sweet chink of Guinnies,
The unresisted Eloquence of Ninnies.
Some of our Women shall be kind to you,
And promise free ingress and egress too.
But if the Faces which we have wo'n't do,
We will find out some of Sixteen for you.
We will be civil when nought else will win ye;
We will new bait our Trap, and that will bring ye.

l.hi: Come, faith let all old breaches now be heal'd,

lg.l: And the said Articles shall be Sign'd and Seal'd.
